150510840.review:
[h3][b]General Information[/b][/h3]
Bendy and the Ink Machine is the first installment of the Bendy Franchise, there is a second major sequel that was released and a mini roguelite survival side game that was released. The game is broken down into multiple Acts/Chapters.

It features a manual save system, where you have to interact with an object to do so. There are also certain points in the game where is auto saves for you, but that is not as common.

It uses a Old Timey Animation Cell Shading art style and darker lighting to set a theme.

[h3][b]My Thoughts[/b][/h3]
The art style in this game is amazing and the game looks beautiful.
The story is compelling enough but it's made all the better by the likable characters they introduce.
Bendy as an Icon is certainly very marketable since it just looks really cool.

Personally, I ran into some very nasty bugs in Chapter 3 where it apparently auto saved in a spot that caused me to be stuck in a wall on reload...the only way to salvage it was to completely play the game over from the start (that was awful). There was also a bug where loading the menu to look at the objectives caused the menu to be forever up until I reloaded the game. Looking online, Chapter 3 is apparently very problematic for many other people. There are reports (I didn't hit this particular bug myself) where the save system itself becomes scuffed and essentially stops being able to save at all, causing people to lose a ton of progress.

The game features an extremely simplistic combat system, it's basically just whacking things with a pipe or axe until it dies. No abilities or dodging to speak of. The puzzles in the game are also pretty simple, nothing too taxing. There is also a fair amount of going back and forth between areas.

[h3][b]Recommendation[/b][/h3]
Personally, I recommend the game. I had a lot of fun with the story and visuals and that alone is worth it to me. However, I can definitely see people finding this game a little boring. I would say set your expectations with this game basically being a pretty walking simulator, that way you aren't going into it expecting a ton of action. If that appeals to you, then I'd say pick it up.

I mentioned it above, but the bugs in this game (specifically chapter 3) are not to be ignored as a non-issue as they are pretty punishing when they happen. The developer doesn't seem to be inclined to fix them, as they have been there for years now. Something to keep in mind when considering your purchase, and how much you want to spend on it.

[h3][b]Gameplay Footage / Shameless Self Promotion[/b][/h3]
If you'd like to check out some game play, I have a YouTube video of my play through here:
https://youtu.be/TGnVtJAp6sI?si=EUwbBDWwhWeVfAId

If you don't mind hitting that subscribe button (it's free), please do so.
Hope this all helps people make up their mind about purchasing the game.

150207879.review: I'd really like to give a positive review but unfortunately from chapter 3 onwards, everything falls apart. It's gone from a horror game to a puzzle action game. The art direction is very original, as is the soundtrack, but sadly that's all that's positive about this game. The story is nice but nothing more, the lore could have been more developed and explained. Combats are pointless, hitboxes are poorly located, puzzles are boring and repetitive, and the game is all about going back and forth, and sometimes dying makes you go faster and is in no way punitive. The fear factor is also quickly lost as the game progresses. Not to mention the mind-numbing number of bugs, save corruption and soft-lock if you go too fast. In short, a forgettable buggy game with a nice look.

INT. THE CRYSTAL MAZE - INK EDITION

The iconic Crystal Maze setup, but with an inky twist. RICHARD O'BRIEN stands at the entrance, ready to welcome the contestants.

RICHARD O'BRIEN
(leaning on the door)
Greetings, intrepid contestants! Welcome to the Ink Maze, a place where creativity meets chaos. Are you ready to dive into the inky abyss?

CONTESTANT 1
(nervously)
Uh, sure, Richard. But where are the crystals?

RICHARD O'BRIEN
(chuckles)
Ah, my dear friend, the crystals are hidden in the darkest corners of the ink-filled studio. Each one guarded by a mischievous ink demon. Good luck!

The contestants, decked out in ink-stained jumpsuits, venture into the first room.

CONTESTANT 2
(squinting)
Is that... is that Boris the Wolf?

RICHARD O'BRIEN
(smiling)
Indeed, it is! Boris will be your trusty sidekick. Just don't let him near the ink machine. We've had some incidents.

Contestant 3 discovers a puzzle involving ink splatters.

CONTESTANT 3
(confused)
Uh, Richard, what do these inkblots mean?

RICHARD O'BRIEN
(grinning)
Ah, the Rorschach Room. Interpret the inkblots, and you'll unlock the path to the next challenge. But beware, some of them might just stare back.

Contestants successfully decipher the inkblots and move to the next room.

CONTESTANT 1
(startled)
Why is Bendy just standing there?

RICHARD O'BRIEN
(smirking)
Ah, the Bendy Challenge. Convince Bendy to dance with you, and you'll earn a crystal. Just remember, he's got two left feet... literally.

Contestants awkwardly dance with Bendy, earning laughter from Richard.

CONTESTANT 2
(freaking out)
Ink monsters! Ink monsters everywhere!

RICHARD O'BRIEN
(laughing)
Ah, the Ink Swarm. Navigate through the ink monsters and retrieve the crystal. It's like a ballet, but with more splatters.

Contestants skillfully navigate through the Ink Swarm, earning applause from Richard.

CONTESTANT 3
(exhausted)
Richard, can we go back to the original Crystal Maze?

RICHARD O'BRIEN
(chuckling)
Ah, my friend, once you've been inked, there's no turning back. But fear not, for you've proven your mettle in the world of Bendy and the Ink Machine!

Contestants exit, covered in ink, but with crystals in hand.

RICHARD O'BRIEN
(smiling)
Well done, my ink-stained adventurers! You've conquered the Ink Maze and survived the whimsical horrors within. Until next time, keep the ink flowing!

The contestants leave, a mix of exhaustion and laughter on their faces.

CONTESTANT 1
(laughing)
That was wild, but I've never had so much fun in ink!

CONTESTANT 2
(exhales)
I need a shower, but it was worth it. Richard's a mad genius.

CONTESTANT 3
(grinning)
Let's do it again. Maybe with extra ink next time.

The Ink Maze adventure becomes a legendary tale in Crystal Maze history.

FADE OUT.

149755982.review:
Bendy and the ink machine has been really important for me throught all these years: it`s a community driven series with interesting ideas and atmosphere. Thought, i`ll do my best to keep away my bias while writing this review.
[olist]
[*]Gameplay:
It may feel really slow and repetitive at times. Ch 3 (even with being my favourite) suffers from this the most: you`ll go through a lot of fetch quests that aren`t rewarding or satisfying to do.
[*]Combat:
Combat sometimes makes this game /hard/ for reasons that weren`t intended. Hit, step, repeat...It could`ve been improved with making the combat system *a bit* more complicated.
Also hitboxes of some enemies have weird placement which means that there`s huge chance that you`ll miss while hitting them.
[*]Characters:
The ink demon, the titular character and main anti-hero, lacks screentime in his own game. 
He either doesn`t appears where it could have been possible to implement him (most of ch4 and ch5) OR he gets overshined by other characters.
In general, BATIM introduces a lot of characters that it can`t always use to their full potential. It could be fixed with either planning story before making games or by making games with smaller character cast.
[*]Lack of some basic features:
- You`ll be forced to do small stealth sections without being able to crouch/peek around the corners
- You can`t skip custscenes on your replays
- Sometimes game lacks any directions and it`s not clear what are you supposed to do (but it`s mostly linear so it`s fine)
- Saving system is buggy and the way it works could be improved
[*]Bugs:
- You`ll loose your progress a lot,especially in ch3. Limited amount of save stations doesn`t help at all.
- Boris can fall throught the floor/elevator can stop working/hearts quest can bug (all in ch3) which may softlock you from continying the game.
- Vizual bugs/ character AI bugs can happen too.
[/olist]
Talking about good things, i recommend checking the game for story, characters or artstyle. Even with all flaws, it still can be a good experience that i genuinely enjoy.

The game has gorgeous graphics and interesting horror aspects to it, but the game contains many game breaking bugs and it shows. I have played the game 3 times so far due to failed saves, and glitches where it leads you to inescapable rooms. 149288700.review:
A former employee of a popular oldies cartoon studio returns after years to find it overrun with pipes full of ink that corrupt and create ink demons that chase you.  Simple premise that works.
This game has a "Bioshock meets old-school Walt Disney meets Five Nights at Freddy's" vibe, and it's amazing.
Controls are simple: Walk, run(ish), jump, attack with weapon (when you have one), interact.  You can fight some enemies, but when the "Ink Demon" appears you need to RUN.  You're no Doom marine, you're a former cartoonist so don't expect crazy combat.
Voice acting and music/ambiance are top notch creepy.  
The scares are mostly jump scares and some tension when you think you're about to be chased.
My only gripe about this was that I played this on my Steam Deck for about 2 hours or so, noticed that I wasn't getting achievements, then got stuck in Chapter 4.  When I turned off the game, the data was gone.  Back to Chapter 1.  At least I learned a few things and got back to Chapter 3 quickly enough.  Doesn't seem like a long game, but some of the fetch quests took me a while to find the last item even in the limited map.  
The save issue was almost a deal breaker, but if this jump-scare-by-Steamboat-Willy aesthetic works for you, give it a try.

Find all 5 hearts and turn them in before pausing or leaving the game.  I can't be bothered to start the game over to beat this and I cannot get a refund due to play time. 149168126.review:
I very much enjoyed Bendy and the Ink Machine. It's a fun little game that fills an interesting niche.
However, I cannot recommend the game in the state I played it in - a state it has apparently been in for years.

Frequent bugs and issues arose that made just playing the game a chore. Infinite save bugs that will erase your progress if you don't catch them early, triggers not firing that required reloading, and the piece de resistance: multiple hardlocks that require you to begin the game again - FROM THE BEGINNING.

The first time this happened to me I was not prepared. The second time I manually had a backup save elsewhere on my PC to avoid it.
Two different spots. Two different locks. Both entirely unreasonable.
The fact that these were never patched is quite honestly baffling to me. As such, I cannot recommend this game unless you have way too much time on your hands to deal with frustratingly bugged play.

148711166.review:
[h1]Buggy & Uninspired[/h1]

Most importantly: this game needs a revisit by the devs. I made it to the last chapter & loaded a save only to find myself stuck in limbo in a small room with only locked doors. You can't manually manage saves & reload a previous one, so the "solution" online was to restart the game from the beginning. Not the first person this has happened to either, and not the only spot in the game this can happen.

On top of crashes & save bugs, there are just a lot of missing QoL features. Support for >60 FPS & keymap rebinds are the two that immediately come to mind.

The game itself is alright. It's immediately presents a unique story with compelling and promising aesthetics, but it then fails to follow through in any front. The gameplay is bland and wonky, the "puzzles" are often just collect-athons and time wasters, and you'll do more walking than anything.

Horror games tend to interrupt the walking and puzzles often with, y'know, horror elements. But this game is anything but scary. There are little to no stealth mechanics. Instead, when faced with most enemies, you're just given a big axe to swing. What is scary about one-shotting crawling ink balls? The only time I was "scared" were cheap jump scares.

Overall, don't waste your time, even without the save bugs. 2/10.

Biggest challenge: bugs that prevent you from saving or progressing.

The game was creepy at first since I came in completely blind to the series. Didn't know what to expect or what the game play would be like.

Ch 1: 4.5/5 (Nice introduction pacing)
Ch 2: 3.5/5 (Okay introduction into the rest of the game play)
Ch 3: 4/5  (Story picks back up)
Ch 4: 3/5 (Eh)
Ch 5: 0.5/5 (Absolutely hated the ending. If the devs read this, I hope you scrap chapter 5 and redo it entirely.)

Overall, I appreciate the game and had fun. Great for indie standards especially, but the last chapter was just a complete insult to the prior points of the game.

148233432.review:
Bendy and the Ink Machine is a great horror game. Easy 8/10.

It is a pretty simple horror game in terms of gameplay. Most of it is exploring environments, listening to audio logs, and finding collectibles while completing simple objectives the game gives you. The game is 5 Chapters long and my first playthrough only took me about 3 hours.

Characters and story are very interesting. Exploration and combat are simple and satisfying with some interesting world puzzles. None of the puzzles were too hard unlike other survival horror games. The art style is very 1920's cartoons with black, white, and parchment-yellow colors. Loved it!

HOWEVER I did run into a few issues with the game. During my first attempt of a playthrough, I got the seemingly infamous "autosave bug". Everytime the game autosaves, a little Bendy head appears in the lower right corner of the screen. It only appears for maybe a second if the game autosaves successfully. But when this bug occurs, the autosave head will not go away and the game will never properly save. I sadly got this bug on my first attempt at a playthrough and upon finishing Chapter 1 and quitting for my first play session, I came back to the game the next day and my save was nonexistent.

Next problem I ran into was on my next attempt at a playthrough. It was something that is actually in the game as a feature but the game doesn't even tell you about. So when you start a new game, if you choose "Chapter Select" instead of "New Game", the game will begin on the chapter you choose but DISABLES SAVES! So if you are a dingus like me and choose "Chapter Select" instead of "New Game", you lose any progress during that play session. Sadly, I had made it to Chapter 3 in my first session of my 2nd playthrough attempt. I quit the game, then the next day booted up to see that the game to see that, once again, I had no save.

TLDR: Game is great, in every aspect, however I had a lot of trouble with the lack of information with starting a new game and the infamous "autosave bug" deleting my first ever save.

On to Bendy and the Dark Revival next and I am hoping that game has less oddness when it comes to the save system.

148134630.review:
I was looking forward to this game. Even recorded the first two chapters for the internet. Then I get to chapter 3... and find a bug that breaks the entire game. Two, actually. One was fixed by a friend remoting in and fixing it, and that was the options menu Black Screen of Death. My friend and I are not game devs, we shouldn't have to fix bugs on a game that's been out as long as this one as. I was willing to overlook that, until I got to the game breaking bug.

I'm in chapter 3, trying to finish one last fetch quest, and the last of the items I need to collect is nowhere to be found. I do my circles, anxiety building, thinking maybe I just overlooked it. Nope, still can't find it. So I turn to google to see if there's a bug or if I'm still missing something. As it turns out, it's a bug that prevents you from being able to progress, one that's been a major issue since 2018.

So here I sit, with a game I was so eager to play despite not being a horror gamer, with one of the most popular indie horror games being totally unplayable. Money wasted (can't get the refund) and 4 hours of my life I can't get back. If you want a game that doesn't have game breaking bugs and issues that should have been resolved long ago, look elsewhere. This game has gone the way of the fictional studio.

147825477.review: It game is actually a lot of fun when it works. It has a great atmosphere and really gives you that "creepy Mickey Mouse" vibe. The puzzles aren't too difficult and the overall game play is smooth.  That's the positives about the game and if there weren't any negatives I would easily give this a positive recommendation.  However, the first time I played this game I was doing a series for my YouTube channel and ran into two bugs I'd consider game breaking. First, don't ever pause the game.  If you forget your objective it is listed on the pause menu but it's a bit of a coin flip regarding getting rid of the pause menu.  The game might unpause while leaving the pause overlay on the screen.  The only way to remove it it to close the game... hope you saved recently.  Speaking of saving, the second bug I ran into is the game stopped saving.  I lucked out and made it passed Chapter 3 (one of the longest chapters) but saving stopped working in Chapter 4. Looking at other recommendations, it appears that this seems to be a bug that plagues a lot of players so it's not uncommon.  When going back to try and get all the achievements I had to replay Chapter 4 just to get to Chapter 5 resulting in a colossal waste of time.  If the developers would fix these VERY basic game breaking bugs the game would be a real treat and it's a shame that they don't appear to have any interest in doing so... it's been out for 6 years by now. My apologies to the rest of the development team, you all did fantastic work, but this game simply is not working properly.

147075018.review:
I really enjoyed the story and game-play in this one.  The characters are all great and the voice acting is also great.  There is a bit of slight repetitiveness on one of the chapters, but that was most likely because of the way i played the game, having done a lot of exploring before proceeding with the story.  Overall definitely a recommend, however....  There is a lot of bugs in the game that i noticed in my first playthrough, and many more in later ones.  None were really game breaking for me during the first run, but they were for others, and I had a great deal of trouble with them on later runs myself.

As for bugs, here's what I encountered:
-The menu would sometimes be stuck on screen and you'd have to close the game to fix it.
-Sometimes the save system would mess up and you'd have to close and restart to fix it.  It will just stop saving and the save icon will either not work at all or stay on screen, when you notice this you have to restart.  First time i didn't notice it was a problem i lost 2 chapters of progress, another time, it completely deleted my save file entirely for the 2nd profile (first one was fine still).
-One time i was trapped in a room with doors that should have been opened and weren't after reloading the checkpoint, soft-locking me from continuing, and replaying chapters doesn't allow you save either, so I would have to restart the entire game to fix that.
-One time one of the scripted events didn't happen, [spoiler]After the Sammy fight and you have to fall through the floor in the narrow hallway afterwards with the boards[/spoiler] and so I forced it to happen on my own by [spoiler]breaking the board with my axe and falling down, which caused Alice to follow my in to the next room, but none of the doors worked in that next room[/spoiler].

These bugs however, were only really apparent on future playthroughs, they were not enough to give a bad review cause I did really enjoy my first run through the game.

------------------------------
Control Scheme I Used:  Keyboard and Mouse with default bindings.  Mostly OK, but the mouse sensitivity would go very weird (usually turn up a crazy amount) if the the framerate drops too low in certain areas.  I would often have to close other things I was doing and set the quality down in the game to fix this, even though I have a fairly competent computer I think.  Probably some bug with the Unity engine.

------------------------------
Worth the current price (CDN$ 24.99)?  Yeah, that's a fair price I'd say, little short but definitely good, wish it wasn't as buggy but that doesn't really take much away from the first playthrough you do.
What I actually paid: $7.37

------------------------------
Completionist Review:
DLC Achievements: No DLC.
Rating:  Not too bad, missing a single item require a full 2nd playthrough of the chapters though, but not the whole game.
Can be completed in one run:  Two chapters I believe would have to be redone
Chapter Select: There is, although no real indication of which need to be done other than the achievements themselves.
Did I need/use a guide?  Oh yes, for sure, on lots of them.

The bugs I encountered really made some of the achievements very painful to get, specifically the save bug, or being soft-locked, etc.  Not being able to save in chapters is super annoying too.  Past this it's not really super bad, there's collectibles, a couple skill based things... not horrible if you dont take into account the bugs.

147044199.review:
es un juego que ha atraído la atención de muchos jugadores por su estilo de horror y su estilo de animación retro. A continuación, se presenta una crítica generalmente positiva del juego:

Bendy and the Ink Machine ha ganado popularidad por su estética única y su capacidad para evocar una sensación de nostalgia por los dibujos animados de la vieja escuela. El juego utiliza un estilo de animación en blanco y negro que recuerda a los primeros días de la animación, lo que crea una atmósfera inquietante y distorsionada que sumerge a los jugadores en su mundo.

La narrativa de Bendy and the Ink Machine es intrigante y está llena de misterios por descubrir. Los jugadores asumen el papel de Henry, un antiguo animador, y exploran un estudio de animación abandonado donde ocurren sucesos extraños. La historia se desarrolla gradualmente a medida que se desvelan secretos oscuros y se encuentran pistas en forma de grabaciones y objetos.

El juego ofrece momentos de tensión y sustos que mantienen a los jugadores alerta y en vilo. La sensación de inquietud se ve reforzada por la música y los efectos de sonido adecuados que acompañan a la experiencia.

Además, la exploración y la resolución de rompecabezas son parte integral de la jugabilidad, lo que agrega un componente de aventura al juego. Los jugadores deben buscar pistas y objetos mientras avanzan a través de los niveles.

Sin embargo, algunas críticas pueden incluir que el juego podría haber aprovechado aún más su potencial de horror, ya que algunos jugadores pueden encontrarlo menos aterrador de lo esperado. Además, la jugabilidad puede volverse repetitiva en ciertos momentos.

146862291.review:
I'll be honest, I was gonna give this game a positive recommendation because as a whole, I did enjoy my experience with it. And then I remembered I ran into a bug where the game does not save at all. That tipped my recommendation immediately, because this game has been out for over six years now, hundreds--maybe thousands of people reported this bug, and the developers [i]still have not fixed it by 2023[/i], despite having enough time to make an entire sequel. Anyway, onto the actual game now.

Chapter 1: Great. 

Great atmosphere, great setting, mysterious ambiance, short and to the point. Does a fantastic job of getting you immersed into the world and plot. Plus the visuals in the factory are outstanding.

Chapter 2: Good.

Once again, outstanding visuals. I loved the introduction of Sammy Lawrence (for how brief he was in the game), and the voice acting from him and the recordings were all well-done. I even liked some of the puzzles since they were randomly generated and not the same every time. They were kinda fetch quests, but at least they put a little flavor to them instead of "Get the key to open the door to get another key to open another door." This chapter also introduced combat. To be blunt, the combat is ass. Some goomba ink-blobs crawl towards you. You whack them a couple times with an axe. That's it. It's not fun; the monsters aren't scary; no skill is required. The chapter does end with a nice chase sequence though. Sadly, the game does go downhill from here...

Chapter 3: [b]TRASH.[/b]

This is the worst chapter in the series--and yes, I'm including the second game (which I also played). You run into Boris, a friendly side character who, after a brief introduction, doesn't really do anything else. The remainder of this chapter is a bunch of annoying fetch quests. You gotta break cardboard cutouts; you gotta get "special" ink, blah, blah, blah. Why? Padding. That's it. And every time you do it, your weapon changes. Why? Because the game said so. Once again, the combat is boring and not fun. The fetch quests are tedious and only exist to waste time. They're not even puzzles or anything fun; you go up some stairs, get the thing, then you have to [i]go all the way back downstairs[/i], and then [b]go all the way back up the damn stairs again![/b] If you cut out these fetch quests, this chapter would be twenty minutes long, probably less.

The only positives I can say about this chapter (besides the visuals), is that the voice acting, once again, is well-done, and this chapter introduces the Ink Demon. Sometimes the Ink Demon will appear at random. And when he does, he will instantly kill you if he catches you. There is no jump scare; there is no big alert; nothing. The game subtly gets darker, you hear him breathing, and you see him slowly stalking around in a room until he disappears. [i]This[/i] was done excellently, and this is a proper way of introducing an unbeatable antagonist in a horror game without resorting to annoying jump scares or over-the-top sequences.

Chapter 4: Great

Maybe it was because I was so pissed off over Chapter 3, but I actually really liked Chapter 4. It's largely due to some of the story "twists" that occur this chapter, along with introducing two surprisingly fun boss fights, which I'm not gonna spoil. Again, great visuals and voice acting, etc. There's a section where you need to stealth past some enemies by distracting them, as opposed to simply whacking them with a weapon. There are two mini-games involving ball-throwing and shooting that I did not like, but apparently if you lose enough times the game makes you win anyway. So that was good. I don't have a lot to say here, mainly because it's heavily story-based and has spoilers.

Chapter 5: Disappointing

Ehhhhhh, yeah. Not a good finale. We team up with two new characters (kind of) and there's one cool sequence where we all fight together against the ink blobs. That was fun. What was not fun is when you get separated from them, lose your weapon, and then have to go on [i]another[/i] boring fetch quest that is done to pad the game's length. Sure, you have to avoid the Butcher Gang here, but when you find the item that you need, all you gotta do is sprint back and forth to that area. This section would've been so much better if the item in question randomly spawned in this maze, thereby forcing you to be stealthy. Because when you know where the item is, there's no need to bother being sneaky. There's a boss fight that amounts to whacking a guy, running away, whacking him again, rinse and repeat. And the final boss fight amounts to finding four switches, flipping them, and avoiding a big monster charging through a maze. There's another section to this fight, but that also isn't difficult. Or fun. And then there's some cutscenes, and the game ends.


Overall, in spite of my issues with this game, I was intrigued with the artstyle, the worldbuilding, the lore, and even some of the characters (the ones who actually did anything). Not a big fan of the combat, but I did like a couple of the boss fights. And the ending was disappointing.

Man, I really wish Steam had a middle recommendation. Because I don't [i]hate[/i] this game in spite of my frustrations, but I can't recommend this game either. And it's because of that bug I talked about earlier. I know, I know; there's a workaround to make it so that you can unlock all the chapters. But I should not have to hunt down a workaround online just to make the game [i]tolerable[/i]. It doesn't fix the save bug either; it just unlocks all the chapters. If the game or your computer crashes in the middle of Chapter 3, you gotta start all that shit over. Sorry! I would be more lenient on this game if I played it when it came out and I found this bug, but several years have passed. The developers found enough time to make both a sequel and a spin-off game. Why the fuck haven't they fixed this bug?

So yeah, I can't recommend this game. And judging by the recent reviews, I'm not the only person who ran into this bug. And even then, the game still has other issues with it. It's weird, because I would recommend you play the sequel, but the sequel ties heavily into the story of the first game....which I would not recommend.

Ain't that a bitch?

Bendy and the Ink Machine has a decent story that gets tainted by its sluggish, boring, chore of a gameplay.
Everything is slow, even your running. Almost every objective is a fetch mission. When you die you have to walk slowly to revive. Stealth is useless and boring since hiding and waiting for the enemies to go away takes a lot of time. My point is, everything about the gameplay is tedious and feels like a way to prolong its time to complete.
Horror would be a stretch to describe this game. Not even a single time has it manage to scare me. It involves cheap jumpscares and a big monster chasing you and that's the whole gist. 
While the story might be worthwhile, i would need to dive deeper to decide fairly. Not to say that the story makes it a must play.
Bendy and the Ink Machine caters to streamers, youtubers and children through and through. Unless you are in that demographic i absolutely recommend you to avoid it. If you are really intrigued about its story, watching someone else play it would be the better option.

146412943.review:
Nos encontramos ante un juego de esos en los que la balanza de la recomendación o no está muy pareja y resulta difícil tomar una decisión objetiva, es mejor probarlo por uno mismo y extraer un veredicto.

La historia de este juego se muestra a trompicones, en principio encarnamos a Henry Stein, e invitado por nuestro socio Joey Drew nos encontramos en un estudio de dibujos animados de los años 20 que tuvo mejor gloria pero que poco a poco ha ido sucumbiendo al éxito y a las extrañas prácticas de este último, se nos narra en cinco capítulos donde aparecen otros personajes relacionados con "la tinta" que no desvelaré y cómo la estrella del estudio Bendy, ha degenerado en un monstruo y a partir de los rituales han aparecido numerosos engendros creados a partir de tinta. Punto de vista atractivo el de la historia, pero la forma de darla a conocer es a veces anodina, siendo los dos primeros capítulos bastante vulgares, mejorando el tercero y sacando lo mejor del juego en los dos últimos.

En algunos momentos dará la sensación de estar jugando a algo parecido a "Bioshock", pero solo por la ambientación y la forma de dar detalles de la historia con las grabadoras, pero nada más lejos de la realidad, este juego está a años luz.

Un aspecto negativo dentro del juego es su duración, es bastante escasa, aparecen más horas por sacar alguno de los logros, y lo que es peor, buena parte de esas horas las pasaremos dando vueltas de un lado para otro buscando objetos que nos pidan, o huyendo de algún enemigo, lo que acrecienta la sensación de aburrimiento.
 
Gráficamente el juego es muy original, la sensación de encontrarnos en una película de animación de los años 20 está conseguida, el entorno gráfico está cuidado aunque pasado un tiempo de juego se vuelve monótono, el tono sepia llega a ser cargante y todo se ve sin variedad, los escenarios son muy similares unos a otros y cuando se recorren a la larga aburren, puesto que en muchas ocasiones son pasillos interminables, además de la poca interacción con elementos del entorno, que a veces no está clara.

La jugabilidad es en primera persona, movimiento bastante tosco, al personaje le cuesta arrancar a moverse, y es algo frustrante puesto que aparte de la exploración, habrá muchos momentos "survival horror" estilo "Amnesia" en los que deberemos correr para escapar de monstruos, deberemos resolver puzzles sobretodo de encontrar piezas que necesitemos para progresar u objetos que nos pidan; a veces nos tendrán de recadero dando vueltas de un lado para otro chocando con objetos y teniendo que combatir con enemigos, como digo excepto los dos últimos capítulos que mejoran, el resto son más bien insípidos en este sentido. Además, hay lucha en primera persona y ésta resulta decepcionante, dar golpes a los enemigos es una odisea, porque no se puede esquivar, te dan sin poderlo evitar y el movimiento es tosco a más no poder, dicho sea de paso, la variedad de enemigos es muy escasa, cuatro engendros hechos de tinta y un par de los que hay que huir y esconderse con relativa facilidad. Y un par de jefes finales. Si nos matan reaparecemos muy cerca de donde se produzca la muerte, en unas estatuas de Bendy,

El aspecto sonoro es decente, con unas voces en inglés logradas y efectos sonoros adecuados, la banda sonora es escasa pero algunas piezas son buenas, está traducido pero existen algunas faltas de ortografía y en la fuente principal los acentos aparecen con otra tipología al no disponer de ellos, algo que se ve bastante cutre.

En definitiva lo que más llamará la atención de este título es su ambientación, el tono sepia tan original y una historia pasable, que comienza francamente mal para ir mejorando poco a poco, el ejemplo a seguir es el de los dos últimos episodios, más variados y redondos, con una jugabilidad más ágil, mayor variedad en entornos y enemigos, premiar la exploración y mayor desafío sería un juego bastante interesante, este primer Bendy parece más bien una prueba. A duras penas lo puedo recomendar.

NOTA 5/10

This is... a very tentative "yes".

This is a horror walking sim. There's no other way to describe it.
The atmosphere is stellar, the art style is palpable, and the story is intriguing. But it seems like all of the work went into those 3 things, 

- Character animations are janky
- Gameplay isn't engaging, and repetitive
- Stealth seems like an afterthought of mechanics, but a forefront of necessity
- Combat is more clunky than an N64 game


Overall, this game has a lot of awesome stuff in it for fans of horror. However, I often found myself rage-quitting and coming back to it later.

145654300.review:
[quote]
[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/36214917/]Follow our Curator Page, MMM Reviews, for more in-depth reviews and recommendations[/url]
[/quote]
[i]Bendy and the Ink Machine[/i] is a horror puzzle game set in an old-timey animation studio. You play as a former employee returning to the abandoned studio at the behest of your former employer. It takes place over the course of five chapters, totaling roughly four hours of gameplay, more if you decide to replay chapters.

[h2]Presentation[/h2]
The most striking element of [i]Bendy and the Ink Machine[/i] is the visuals. Every environment is depicted with thick black edges and imprecise lines, making the world appear like a cartoon from the 1930s. It’s such a unique art style that is executed almost perfectly. One of the best effects the visuals have is highlighting what doesn’t fit into the cartoon world. Globs of ink drip from the ceiling, ink creatures roam the floors, contrasting with the studio itself. They don’t have the same art style, instead being shown with relatively standard 3D graphics. It’s an interesting stylistic decision that works in tandem with the art design to give weight to the horror elements. The world of [i]Bendy[/i] feels familiar, but with something sinister beneath the surface.

On the other hand, I felt that the animations could’ve used some work, especially the player’s animations which looked stiff and uncomfortable. They weren’t horrible, but they didn’t complement the cartoon aesthetic as well as the lighting or art direction did. Similarly, I found the voice acting passable, but it never stood out as one of the game’s strengths.

[h2]Gameplay[/h2]
Within the first thirty minutes, you quickly get a feel for what the whole game will be like. It’s horror blended with a walking simulator, puzzles, and light combat mechanics. Depending on the chapter, there will be a different focus, but for the most part, you’ll be getting one of these three concepts. I found the walking simulator portions to be the strongest; they build tension very well, don’t overstay their welcome, and when they include a jumpscare it feels earned rather than lazy or cheap. You have time to walk around and take in the environment, playing to the game’s visual strengths.

Unfortunately, the puzzle and combat portions were tedious, uninteresting, and killed any atmosphere and tension the game had previously. I generally enjoy puzzles, but most of the ones in [i]Bendy[/i] consist of a checklist of items you need to collect, rather than something you need to think about and actually solve. There are a couple of genuine puzzles, but they are few and far between, and certainly not strong enough to be worth the wait.

As for the combat, I felt that it could have been removed from the game without missing much. You only fight the lesser ink creatures and they are quite easy to defeat. They would feel scarier if you actually had to run from them or sneak past them, but forcing you to kill dozens of them waters down their fear factor. They also exclusively spawn from ink piles, so it’s not much of a surprise when they pop up, you can see it coming from a mile away. To make matters worse, the combat mechanics are rudimentary, boiling down to simply clicking on an enemy once to defeat them. It’s clunky because of an odd invincibility window when enemies spawn, coupled with the fact that combat clearly wasn’t fleshed out or polished in any significant way.

[h2]Performance[/h2]
While graphically it looks great, you can easily tell that it’s not a AA or AAA game when it comes to polish. There are numerous bugs I encountered during my playtime, although only one was significant; when I got stuck between the game and the pause menu, preventing me from moving or exiting and forcing me to alt-f4. For the rest, they were minor issues like getting stuck on part of the level, an NPC failing to trigger the next part of a level, etc. I also encountered odd frame drops a few times, without a clear explanation as to why. I would assume it was during some effects-heavy portion of the game, but it was hard to say exactly what it was, so your mileage may vary.

[h2]Verdict[/h2]
[i]Bendy[/i] was a mixed bag, but I would ultimately recommend it. If you enjoy walking simulator horror with a little bit more interactivity, this could be right up your alley. The art is fantastic, and the horror is usually solid, but it gets let down by some of its more half-baked mechanics. I don’t know if I would pick it up at full price, but it’s unique enough to be worth checking out the next time it goes on sale.

[h2]6/10[/h2]

145567281.review:
At the start Bendy offers a great classic cartoon styled horror game that delivers in spooky ambiance and a charming art direction. Unfortunately, the game very quickly loses steam due to lackluster final chapters and an absolute metric ton of softlocking glitches that will have you restarting the game from scratch. You wouldn't have the need to restart if you could save in chapter select but they did not include that feature. Even when it does save a glitch could have already occurred and there is no way to fix the situation.

Sample Glitches/Bugs:
-Saving can glitch out and even manual saves will stop working (Fix: must restart game if you notice the save icon sticking around)
-Progression triggers can fail to  execute properly. i.e. a lift refusing to move, key items not appearing, or an enemy not going into a kill zone. (restart game and hope it works but not guaranteed)
-Loading into a save can result you being inside a locked room with no escape. (No solution except start a new save)
-etc.

It is utterly disappointing that this game has as many bugs as it does with seemingly no response from the developer and no genuine solutions.

145103561.review:
A Nightmare of Progress Loss - Avoid Bendy and the Ink Machine!

I can't believe I actually wasted my time and money on Bendy and the Ink Machine! This game is an absolute disaster, and I'm beyond frustrated by the complete lack of consideration from the developers. I mean, who in their right mind releases a game in this day and age without a functional save feature? It's mind-bogglingly irresponsible and frankly unethical to sell a game that doesn't even allow you to save your progress.

It's bad enough that they released a broken game, but to compound the issue, they outright refuse to fix it? That's not just laziness; that's a slap in the face to anyone who invested their hard-earned money into this disaster. It's as if they're saying, "Thanks for your cash, now deal with our incompetence."

I've seen mobile games with more advanced save systems than this travesty. It's not just an inconvenience; it's a deal-breaker. Who has hours upon hours to dedicate to a game in a single sitting? Not me, that's for sure. The lack of a save feature turns what could have been a somewhat interesting experience into an exercise in frustration and anger management.

Story line is really fun and interesting, second game was great. Disappointing you can only play this game if you are willing to do it all in one sitting...

Save yourself the headache and avoid this like the plague. Your sanity and wallet will thank you.

145074077.review:
Story, arts & atmosphere would make this game a solid 7/10 at least, BUT oh gosh the movement speed.. It was SOOOO SLOW it felt weirdly unnatural, even when your character is supposedly "running" it feels like he is limping, all the time... And for the same reason, some bosses seems to be purposely made moving VERY slow to compensate for the slow protagonist, thus those boss fight made me feel hilarious (instead of supposedly scary / daunting). The whole pacing and slowness keep making me felt as if the dev purposely did it to extend the player's playtime (since the game is short).

Other than that, the game is also kinda bad news if you care about achievements. Some of the achievements / collectibles require you to immediately turn back to area you've already explored and SPAM interaction keys on stuffs / doors you've probably interacted previously (example: a previously closed door or un-interactable box is now miraculously open-able BUT only right after you successfully cleared the obstacle to the next area, AND you need to backtrack IMMEDIATELY because moving forward would close you off from the collectibles / achievement), and this is without any hint mind you... How is that even fun...? Definitely not a clever design to me.

Lastly, I've also met game-breaking bugs, TWICE! I got stuck in 2 different part of the last chapter, and what's worse, you cannot even restart the chapter, using chapter select would forbid you to save mid-game for gods know why (so you can't re-attempt some achievements at save point), the frustration is REAL, especially when the game is SO SLOW... Everything added-up made me wasted hours for that last achievement... Fortunately at last, I found someone shared a chapter 5 save file online, allowed me to 100% it without needing to restart from the beginning.

5/10 at best due to these astounding experiences, would've given Mixed instead of Recommended if I have the option to.

144826365.review:
[h1] (Not all) Dreams come true [/h1]

Pese a las horas que he invertido en este juego, tras meditarlo, no puedo recomendarlo, pues aún en su estado actual, se siente como un juego a medio desarrollar, con múltiples problemas que pueden llegar a afectar a la jugabilidad.

La premisa era buena, y el planteamiento de lo más original, pero se nota muchísimo que es un proyecto hecho sobre la marcha, y las diferencias entre los distintos capítulos son abismales, además de que la coherencia y la cohesión entre los mismos es bastante pobre. 

Asimismo los primeros dos capítulos se sienten cortos y superficiales, si bien son los que mejor logran "rescatar" la tensión y el terror del juego. Quizá en un juego con 20 capítulos se notaría menos la poca profundidad, pero al ser uno de 5, se nota muchísimo que estos dos primeros están prácticamente vacíos.

En otro tercio, el capítulo tercero de [i]Bendy and the Ink Machine[/i], se hace de lo más pesado ya que en este se nos obliga a hacer tareas absurdamente repetitivas e insustanciales, que no dejan de ser pobres excusas para alargar la experiencia de juego de manera agónica.

Finalmente, los capítulos cuarto y quinto, son en mi opinión los más interesantes del juego, y es que, en mi opinión, si este estuviese compuesto por seis o siete capítulos como estos dos últimos, quizá mereciese más la pena, pues al contrario que sus antecesores son más profundos, y se nota en ellos que se aspira a una mayor seriedad narrativa.

Por último, en lo relativo al terror, como comentaba un poco más arriba, a mi no me ha parecido muy allá, y tensión lo que se dice tensión la genera en los primeros dos capítulos, luego se convierte en un cutre pilla-pilla con algún [i]screamer[/i] ocasional. Idóneo para quienes les guste el terror en dosis micro, un poco meh para mí.

En resumen, el apartado artístico es soberbio, y las premisas sobre las que el juego pretendía erigirse de lo más creativas, ahora bien, el resultado a mí me parece bastante mediocre, por no decir decepcionante. Esperaba algo más.

144657262.review:
The art is the main attraction here. Overall stylization and the sepia effect have some special charm. Gameplay wise it is mostly good, I think the most disappointment for me was the 5th chapter, because it made it much more obvious that fighting mechanic was bad (the delays, the lack of impact), and AI was... Strange? There is a stealth-like part in the 5th chapter and I was noticed once, ran away (even without hiding) and then I have not seen any of the 3 monsters. I heard them somewhere, but they did not appear. The final fight with Bendy had a similar problem, since it did not look like Bendy was targeting me at all, even during tubes stage. All in all, I think it would have been better if this was just a puzzle game with "horror" elements.
What also was good was the story, or rather the lore. I definitely want to learn more about this ink-world and how it is connected to real world. Too bad the ending of this game did not answer any questions, but there are 2 more games in the series, so maybe they will clarify things.
Anyway, if you do like exploratory kind of games and like the art style of this one in particular, I can recommend it. Not sure if at full price, but it's not that big of a sum, too, but the game is roughly 4-5 hours, so it will depend on personal preference, I guess.

143526700.review:
La gran mayoría de los survival horror indie están inspirados en los Resident Evil y/o los Silent Hill, por ello es de agradecer propuestas diferentes como Bendy and the Ink Machine. Con una muy efectiva estética de dibujos animados de años 30 en tonos ocres y negros, y una original historia, el juego es una mezcla de exploración, sigilo y combate cuerpo a cuerpo (en este último aspecto es muy mejorable). Controlaremos al socio co-fundador de un estudio de dibujos animados explorando las viejas instalaciones del estudio y descubriendo que está poblado por monstruos de tinta, así como que varios de sus personajes (no necesariamente amistosos) han cobrado vida. El combate lo realizaremos con tuberías, hachas, llaves mecánicas, etc. Además de mediocre y repetitivo (todo el rato golpear y retroceder) es muy tosco. Por ello los momentos boss-fight no son precisamente memorables. Los golpes restan bastante salud, así que la mejor opción tras recibir uno es alejarse los segundos que tarda en reestablecerse totalmente. La exploración y el sigilo están bastante mejor, ayudados por la poderosa estética del entorno. Tendremos armarios donde escondernos de los enemigos. Aunque a los más comunes los podremos eliminar, hay zonas en los que deberemos usarlos por ir desarmados o porque el enemigo es inmortal. 


El juego tiene un problema inaceptable, y más teniendo en cuenta que el juego es de 2017 y debería ya estar corregido: A partir del capítulo 4 el sistema de salvado está buggeado. Me ha pasado (y por lo que leo a muchos otros), que salgo del juego tras el último boss del capítulo 4 o incluso tras la horda del 5 y cuando lo retomo me encuentro que el juego me manda al inicio del capítulo 4, a pesar de todos los puntos de control que he pasado desde ahí hasta el punto en el que salí. Así que debéis saber que los dos últimos capítulos (4 y 5) debéis jugarlos de un tirón u os arriesgáis a perder todo el progreso. Y para rematar la faena, hay un momento en el capítulo 5 (tras acabar con la horda) en que estoy atascado sin saber qué hay que hacer para avanzar, dando vueltas como pollo sin cabeza en busca de algún ítem o alguna salida. Hasta que miro vídeos en Youtube y en absolutamente todos un NPC se va hacia una puerta y la abre (???). Entiendo que es un bug que se ha producido durante la pelea con la horda, porque salgo de la partida (otra vez a empezar desde el capítulo 4…) repito todo y esta vez el NPC sí abre la puerta (???).  En la práctica he tardado bastante más tiempo en terminar el juego por todos estos errores. Me parecen lo suficientemente graves como para poner una reseña negativa, pero bueno, estoy de buen humor y la voy a dejar positiva por los muchos aspectos destacables que tiene el juego (que aún así me parece que está más hypeado de lo que merece).

142625935.review:
The main problem with this game is that it's just too easy. The only challenge in the game comes from completing the achievements, but the achievements are broken in a way that you must replay the game several times to actually get them since simply using the chapter select, for some bizarre reason, does not save your progress. The sepia-toned visuals make the game very interesting in terms of atmosphere, but the story is so nonsensical that it doesn't really feel like you're progressing in any meaningful way. I'm not really sure how to relate the idea of this story since it seems improvised ad hoc as the developers were designing the nonsensical levels. I think you play as animator, I'm not sure, and you start out in an animation studio before descending into some insane mess of wooden tunnels that don't exist with any rhyme or reason. I suppose that alone would make the game interesting, but problems arise when you start to see multiple versions of the same three characters showing up in the game without really getting any explanation as to why. I think the ink machine in the title is what's creating the characters, but there's no explanation as to what's going on so it doesn't really matter. It's basically just your "demon is chasing after you" trope tied up with a bunch of stream of consciousness level designs. 

Essentially, you move around, manipulate switches, pick up items, and collect cans of bacon soup that serve no purpose and are way to ubiquitous throughout the levels since they serve no purpose other than to provide an achievement. And honestly if the achievements were a fair challenge I would give this game a positive rating, since they are the only thing that provides a challenge in the game, but they are broken and glitched. For one, some unlock seemingly at random, like one that said I listened to all the audio logs in a level when I only listened to one. 

The problem is that without the achievements this is essentially just a walking simulator with no real puzzles or challenges other than figuring out where to go. It's essentially Bioshock, which is a clone of System Shock, which is a game that came out 30 years ago and only justified its infinite respawns by making the combat complex and difficult. In this game you almost always have a melee weapon, and survival just means whacking the enemy and retreating before you die. The combat is atrocious, but there isn't much of it, so it almost doesn't matter. Beyond that, quite often the game encourages you to get annoyed wandering aimlessly because you needed to open the crate after you triggered some random scripted event, even though you walked past it and tried to open it five minutes ago. I get that it's essentially an indie game, but since it's so easy and random it comes across as being amateurish and irritating rather than creative and quirky. I really do like the Bendy character though, and the various other animations. The voicework on Alice Angel is also very good. There are only three boss fights and they are barely boss fights since in two of them it's impossible to fail. There's a carnival ride boss that looks really creepy and intimidating but since he doesn't actually do anything but spin around there is no actual challenge since you can simply stand outside of his spin radius and avoid all damage. I can't really buy that this is intended as a children's game since it involves cultists, murder and has a bunch of adult themes running through it. However, even if it was a children's game there still needs to be some pass or fail element to justify it actually being a game. As I said, some of the achievements are challenging, but you have to play through the game like five times to get them since the auto-save is broken and if you chapter select you don't get to save and thus cannot even unlock some of the achievements this way. This leaves me with a game where i feel like I've accomplished nothing because there was no real challenge, and in trying to find a challenge end up more disappointed because the structure of it doesn't justify investing 40 hours to be a completionist for what is otherwise a mediocre and meaningless experience.

142146707.review:
It's meh.

The horror atmosphere had me in the beginning, but lost me super quickly after that. There were a few moments throughout the game where I did feel afraid, but largely I just felt bored.

Gameplay is underwhelming. There's a bunch of repetitive fetch quests, enemy AI is too poor to make any stealth sections feel engaging, combat is stiff and shallow, movement is sluggish, and the "puzzles" can hardly be considered as such.

Story is barren. In terms of narrative very little happens throughout the game.

The game's strongest point is definitely it's aesthetic. It nails the old-timey cartoon look, and you can really tell a lot of love and creativity went into the visual aspects.

I really wanted to like this game but overall I can't think of any reasons to recommend it :(

142118684.review:
I've been playing Bendy for 6 years now, recently during this years summer sale I decided not to be a pirate and actually purchase the game that I've sunken dozens of hours into.

Originally daunted by the games 60 achievements, I was pleasantly surprised to learn that not a single achievement was even slightly irritating to obtain. They all felt very fair and satisfying to achieve. The game is what Indie "horror" should be and is often treated as the start of the streak of shitty indie horror titles (Poppy Playtime and Garten of BanBan to be specific). It is simply not, this game is a wonderful experience with fantastic art direction helping it keep a really solid identity all these years later.  Bendy is an excellent game, and a pleasant completion experience.

Edit: This game has a stupid save glitch that has caused me to have to restart chapter 4 3 times now... So it's also buggy af, buy it on consoles if you can

[h1]A Thrilling and Atmospheric Adventure[/h1]

[b]Bendy and the Ink Machine[/b] is an exceptional game that combines elements of [b]horror[/b], [b]puzzle-solving[/b], and [b]exploration[/b]. From the moment I started playing, I was captivated by its unique [b]art style[/b] and immersive [b]storytelling[/b].

The game takes place in a [b]creepy animation studio[/b] where you play as Henry, a former animator who returns to the studio after receiving a [b]mysterious invitation[/b] from his old friend. As you navigate the [b]dark corridors[/b] and unravel the secrets of the [b]ink-infested world[/b], the tension and suspense build up, keeping you on the edge of your seat.

One of the standout features of [b]Bendy and the Ink Machine[/b] is its stunning [b]visuals[/b]. The [b]black-and-white aesthetic[/b], reminiscent of classic cartoons, creates a [b]nostalgic[/b] yet [b]eerie atmosphere[/b]. The attention to detail in the studio's design and the [b]grotesque ink-based creatures[/b] you encounter truly adds to the game's [b]unsettling ambiance[/b].

The [b]gameplay mechanics[/b] are [b]intuitive[/b] and well-implemented. Solving puzzles and uncovering hidden secrets is both [b]challenging[/b] and [b]rewarding[/b]. The occasional encounters with [b]hostile ink monsters[/b] provide a sense of [b]urgency[/b] and keep you constantly on guard. The pacing of the game is well-crafted, with moments of [b]intense action[/b] interspersed with quieter exploration segments.

The [b]narrative[/b] of [b]Bendy and the Ink Machine[/b] is [b]engrossing[/b] and filled with [b]twists and turns[/b]. As you progress, you'll gradually piece together the [b]dark history[/b] of the studio and the [b]sinister events[/b] that occurred within its walls. The [b]voice acting[/b] and [b]audio design[/b] are top-notch, further enhancing the immersive experience.

While the game's length is relatively short, with [b]five chapters[/b] that can be completed in a few hours, each chapter offers a unique setting and a fresh set of challenges. The [b]replay value[/b] is high, as there are hidden collectibles and secrets to discover, encouraging multiple playthroughs.

Overall, [b]Bendy and the Ink Machine[/b] is a must-play for fans of [b]atmospheric horror games[/b]. Its captivating story, captivating visuals, and well-crafted gameplay make for an [b]unforgettable experience[/b]. Prepare to be immersed in the [b]ink-soaked world[/b] of Bendy and uncover the [b]dark secrets[/b] that lie within.

[strike][b]Rating: 9/10[/b][/strike]

This is the worst horror game I have ever played in terms of gameplay. Yes, it is scary sometimes? But overall not a game to play if you want to have fun. You are put to such time consuming tasks, horrible boss battles, excruciating "stealth" sections, and cheap combat.

[spoiler] This game is another one of those games where the ending is going back to the beginning of the game, which has to be the worst ending that any video game could do. [/spoiler] 

You can tell how many people gave up by looking at the game completion achievement, "To Hell and Back" which only 11.6% of players have gotten. (I also find the name of it quite fitting for what you have to go through in the game, trying to not just quit and move on to a different game).

141964124.review:
I like the game so far and I think the story is neat but thats about all its got going for it. Good atmosphere, great voice acting, awesome story but thats it.

There's terrible forced combat that also somehow punishes you for partaking in the combat you HAVE to do in order to survive.

The puzzles aren't exactly... puzzles. I don't ask for advanced levels of brain teasing in my horror games. But something more complicated then "Grab x items" and "Follow this 4 point order" would be nice? I'm sure the puzzles get harder but the first impression for puzzles isn't great.

Then there's the stability and overall user experience. They really left this in a mess huh? No chapter restarts, no save stats, no control settings, bugs are rampant, glitches galore, and the SOFTLOCKS. If you get a dread softlock, even through no fault of your own, you have to start the game all over again. It baffles me that a game with such a powerful community backing has such a piss poor polish overall.

Get it on a CHEAP sale, or watch one of the thousands of Youtubers play it. Otherwise? No deal.

141953974.review:
The gameplay is boringly simple (although I suppose I shouldn't have expected too much in that regard from this genre). Every task blatantly follows the "find and flip three switches" structure or similar, and feels like it was incorporated purely for the sake of giving you an obstacle to interact with, rather than as a natural part of the story.

This is pretty standard, but while the sepia cartoon studio setting is charming for a little while, it soon wore off for me as everything sorta just looks the same. You see the same props dressing every room.

I also expected witty and lively cartoon characters coming to life, but so far everyone in this game either has a face or a voice, not both. The vast majority are just voice logs, and half of those characters aren't really that memorable or likeable. The writing and voice acting is decent, but nothing spectacular, so for me, it doesn't really do enough to hook me or make me wanna push through the dull gameplay, especially with such a slow walk/run speed.

I made it halfway through Chapter 3. The most similar game to this I've played is Amnesia, which I liked, despite it suffering from some of the same issues, but that was ages ago. If you like these sorts of games and need to scratch the itch for another, then there's a decent chance you'll enjoy it enough, and I hear that the sequel, Bendy and The Dark Revival is better, but personally even at sale price I didn't feel it was really worth my time.

141946389.review:
Okay, so I'm revisiting this game after around three years since I played it and was a big fan of it. Let me get to the positives first.

POSITIVES!
I like the visual style, sure it's all this boring yellow and brown but I must say that it is very visually unique. I like the fan made songs that they included, nice variety of them, sadly Chapter 5 got an original song but either way I like the decision to include them. I also like the concept of just going like 300,000ft underground since Chapter 1, like how do you get back up. The horror is also something I enjoy, it's not scary for most of it, but stuff with the Projectionist  and especially Ink Bendy feel pretty cool and I wish there was more of it. Also going off the visuals, it looks absolutely gorgeous, at the start it was just simple shading but when they released this could make a full game, they made it beautiful. I like the subtle replay value with the seeing glass, it's a neat way to make me wanna play again, and I fell for it, it was actually fun playing looking for these hidden messages. 

NEGATIVES!
Everything after Chapter Two is bad, especially Chapter Three which is (I shit you not) a one hour fetch quest, that sucks ass. And Chapter Five is such a anti climatic end to the game, I don't care about the loop thing, I don't mind the actual ending, what I do mind though is how boring the last Chapter is. I feel like doing another fetch quest is dumb, and they even make fun of that in that Chapter. Characters are terribly voice acted at times. I like the tapes with the employees giving inside prospective on the studio, but the voice acting is bad. The only voices I actually like are Bertrum Piedmont and Joey Drew and maybe some others I'm forgetting. Henry is also not voiced well, it feels like he's trying to be this epic action hero and this wimpy guy half the time. Getting back to the Chapter Five stuff, the Beast Bendy fight is cool but I feel beating him up would be cooler besides just running around. Combat is also not fun, you run so slowly and healing takes unironically like 10 years. This game is also very buggy, especially Chapter Three where both on Consoles and Steam it can just refuse to do the part it's supposed to. This usually only happens if you save and quit then come back to the game, if you do that then it won't work properly and you'll probably have to restart the Chapter again. 

I enjoy the game but I never really want to go back, I just think about it every once and a while.
6/10

I just beat the game, and I am in absolute agreement with the frustration of the bugs in that I too had spent about an hour trying to beat a particular boss - only to come back the next day and realize I had to do it all. over. again. because it didn't save my progress. (That was why I kept seeing the Bendy face for an hour straight at the corner of my screen! I also didn't realize the punch card clocks were save points until nearly the end of the game.)

Aside from that, the atmosphere of creepiness is top-notch, and the score often matches it. The ending, however, left me a bit confuzzled. After looking it up online, the explanation still wasn't much help. There are some questions I still have that I don't feel were ever properly answered. I intend on playing it through with the (admittedly weak) New Game+ perks, but from what I can tell, those questions will still remain and I'm strictly replaying it so I can see what's down the other path I didn't choose the first time around. I still recommend this, though, because as a survival horror game, it's pretty entertaining - even if the battles and constant lack of weapons can be frustrating. Also, the final boss left me thinking - that was it? 

Story: 2/5
Gameplay: 4/5
Score: 3/5 (I wish there was more of it honestly. When it was creepy, it was very creepy - but it was sparse.)

141180538.review:
While the ambiance, visual style and world building are fantastic, this is unfortunately a fundamentally broken game.   Several years back I bumped into a game ruining bug that deleted my save data.  I restarted today (so that I could play through this game before tackling the sequel) and bumped into a yet another, different game breaking bug in chapter 3.  The funny thing is, I KNEW of this bug before I even encountered it since there are dozens of posts discussing it in the community forum.  Despite that knowledge, I wasn't able to avoid it.  You basically have to avoid a a mini-boss while hunting for five items in a small, poorly lit maze.  If the boss manages to kill you (which he did to me), one or more of those items may despawn, making progress literally impossible.  Reloading the game does not fix the issue.  In fact, the game mistakenly assumes you collected all five items while still blocking your progress.  

I really wish I could recommend this game, but after hitting two separate game breaking bugs I just can't.   This game came out 6 years ago so I'm not optimistic about a patch.  Sadily, my recommendation would be to avoid this game because game breaking bugs that ruin your play-through just aren't acceptable.

141149188.review:
I am warning of spoilers under cons section so beware:

PROS: The horror atmosphere is fantastic in this game. It truly captures what made Bioshock & System shock great and turned into it's own IP. Cool semi-cartoon visuals look familiar like it was used by the same engine that TellTale used for their The Walking dead franchise. Eerie soundtrack works perfect with every situation be it walking thru a hallway or defending yourself from ink demons. Voice actors that were used for tape recorders were great with that Boston Italian accent or those strong accents from the Southern states of U.S.A.. The story was also a pleasant surprise especially in chapter 5.

CONS: This game has probably the worst "sprint" in all of games I ever played. To be honest it's slower then a fast walk. Also this game has MAJOR BUG PROBLEMS!!! In chapter 3 I encountered a save file bug which was saving my file for more then an hour. I finished chapter 3 and started to play chapter 4 then left the game. But when I returned to play the game I was taken back to chapter 3 when the save file bug encountered and there I lost my time to play over chapter 3 again. The second bug I encountered was in chapter 5 when I punched my ticket to save the game, I left the game with 2 doors opened for progression. I came back to play the game and I was spawned at the save checkpoint with both of those doors closed and LOCKED! I had to start over chapter 5 for this reason and again losing over an hour of my damn time.

CONCLUSION: Despite in dire need of patches for fixing the bugs I mentioned under cons, I still truly recommend this game because I really had a good time with it and instead of waiting for a brand new entry of Bioshock & System shock, just play this franchise instead because it's interesting, challenging and scary at same time.

One of the worst games I've ever played.

A stellar example of things you don't do to your player. Maybe I was expecting the wrong thing. Maybe I'm wrong for thinking this was more than a Hidden Object point-and-click game, but if I could refund it I absolutely would. The only well done thing about this game is how it captures the feel of Bioshock with the map layouts and musical flourishes.

140802521.review:
I recommend this game only with serious caveats. The most important thing a game needs to get right is the save function. This utterly fails on that score: There is a single save file for multiple saves slots, which is prone to corruption; There is no hard save, only autosaves at checkpoints and using a punch card machine interactive object; You can't save your current game into a new slot, only new games, making the slots effectively useless; There is a well documented save bug that has always been there and is still a problem 5 years after release.

I recommend making frequent backup copies of the game file, called batim.game, in order to have a fallback in case of very likely corruption. Corruption can come in many forms. Chapter 5 is particularly bad for this. There are numerous places in which you can find yourself soft locked on restarting a saved game. Perhaps the worst offender is a punch card machine in a hallway where the doors start out locked. I've punched that machine and then quit and restarted, only to find that I'm then locked in the hallway with no means of progressing. That's very poor.

It has a good concept and feel, and it is a useful starting point to get the backstory of the world before playing the sequel, Bendy and the Dark Revival, which is a great game and superior in just about every respect. If you can stand the issue with game save backups and you can get it on sale, I say go for it. That said, a lot of the game play can be quite tedious, with annoying fetch quests to get done. The final two chapters are more interesting, so it's worth persevering.

140479857.review:
I cannot begin to say how much I love this game. TheMeatly did it right. THIS is how you make a horror puzzle game. I understand that many people have had some issues with how the game is a lot of fetch quests, etc, but to me, they are small parts to learn a rich and amazing story from a great dev team. You can feel the effort they put into it. 

The game started off in chapters, and they slowly built upon one another. Then there were updates, cut, paste, move this here, upgrade this, do that; the team was not afraid to throw out a product and let the fans decide "Hey, maybe you guys should do this." They freaking listened to us and we got this masterpiece. BATDR is another one as well. 

I love this fandom and I love this game. Seriously. Get the game.

If you dream of playing a great game with fun graphics, a 1930's inspired animation that does credit to the time period, good voice acting, lots of machine ASMR, a great storyline, and a ton of fan theories and potential for a great series with devs that care, then trust me: Dreams Do Come True.

140375207.review:
Ok so I finished this and the sequel a while ago and while I did leave a seething review for the sequel, I never left one for this one. So I thought why not? I can even vent my hatred for the sequel even more! So why do I like this one so much more as to leave a positive review than the sequel? Because the game just felt overall much more flushed out than the sequel. The weapons you use get changed pretty frequently as you go along with each one feeling different than the last and helps to keep things somewhat fresh. There is even a secret tommy gun you can get! It doesn't stay with you forever but it is fun. There is also a secret scythe weapon but I never got my hands on it. Meanwhile in the sequel you got to use a pipe for the entire game with lackluster upgrades. Enemy variety is also a lot better and the bosses vary greatly. The only thing I give the sequel over this game (besides graphics and sound) is the final boss being a lot better than the Ink Machines final boss.

This game just felt so much more fleshed out compared to the sequel. The sequel felt like it was trying to do a lot more but just didn't flesh out each feature enough or polished them enough. This game even though its lacking those added features resulted in a better focus on everything else and therefore a better overall experience.

Anyways! Besides all that I do have one more final good note to say about this game: The achievements are not an absolute drag to acquire. I didn't find myself slogging along banging my head against the wall trying to get them all which is always nice! I suggest if your planning on getting this game wait for a sale but I don't see that much harm in getting it at its full price tag either.

139720759.review:
Giving this game a tentative thumbs up, because while the story is awesome and the visuals very unique, the bugs and jank put a [b]severe[/b] hamper on overall experience.

Story wise and world, the game is fantastic. All very unique in terms of visuals and lore. I wish there was more variety in the poster art scattered everywhere, but that’s a minor complaint. The voice acting is good and it all comes together to provide a great experience.

As a survival horror, Bendy & the Ink Machine is pretty light. For the most part, it’s all atmosphere building up the tension. The big bad, the Ink Demon, shows up infrequently and there’s often a box to hide from him in near by. The conventional enemies are far more likely to be the cause of your death. If you’re looking to dip your toe into survival horror, this game is a great starter.

All that said, for me, the absolute worst part of the game was the save system. It broke, severely, within the first 3 chapters. You can tell your save has become corrupted because the Bendy icon, which appears in the bottom right corner of the screen momentarily when your story progress automatically saves or you use a punch machine to manually save, that icon does not go away and just remains on screen. There is no way around it expect to exit the game totally and then restart from wherever it left you off. I had to replay sections of Chapter 2 several times, and parts of Chapter 3 even more. Absolutely ruinous to the immersion and enjoyment of the story. Probably lost a good hour or more of game progress because of that. It seems that if you’re still [i]within[/i] the game, you can reload those saves, but as soon as you exit all that progress is toast. That a game from 2018 should have that buggy a save system is inexcusable. Worst part is that the console version apparently does not have that issue, nor really any other bugs.

The only other truly infuriating bug I had was the fight with Sammy in Chapter 5 bugging out while replaying that chapter after beating the game to try and get one of the achievements.

Aside from that, the game ran fine. No stutters, no noticeable frame drops (on 2560x1440). Achievements popped when they were supposed to.

In the end, Bendy & the Ink Machine is a great introduction to survival horror for anyone new to the genera, or a bit of a light romp with cool story and setting for veterans of that type of game. But due to the appalling levels of jank that it still has (and will never be patched out by this point), if you’re thinking of picking it up, I cannot endorse getting it at full price. Wait for a good sale, and then grab it and its [url=store.steampowered.com/app/1063660/Bendy_and_the_Dark_Revival/]sequel[/url]  (and perhaps [url=store.steampowered.com/app/1236990/Boris_and_the_Dark_Survival]sideqel[/url]).

139472574.review:
I've beaten this game and almost got all achievements for it. The main story lasts about 4h to 5h.
Now let's have a quick review:

The good:
The art and graphics are great and original. The color scheme gives you this old reel vibe, that I believe the creators were after. The enemy design is interesting. The puzzles were fun and not too challenging, which I think is good for a horror game. Most of the voice acting is also great, and the sound design is fitting as well.

The Neutral:
The story didn't really do it for me. I'm not sure if I fully understood what was going on, and why the world/map was the way it is.
The game isn't all that scary. There is always an abundance of light, and when you're being chased, you run at the same speed as your chaser. And due to the linear design of the levels, you'll find a hiding spot eventually. And no matter how far your chaser is behind you, entering a hiding spot ends the chase and keeps you safe. This means that you never really feel threatened.
There are dark bits (with flashlight) in the game and a ventilation shaft part in the game, but the creators didn't really do anything with them.

The not-so-good:
1st of all, this games doesn't let you customize your controls, which is a big no-no for me. The game assumes you've got a QWERTY keyboard, and if you don't, that's on you to fix this.
The combat is clunky. You hit slow and depending on your weapon and enemy, need to hit the enemy multiple times. This ends up becoming you standing in front of the enemy, hitting him a couple of times while he's hitting you, and then running in circles while you're recovering health. This is not interesting gameplay. 
The playable character's voice acting is bad, which is unfortunate as all other characters have great voice acting. The playable character's voice sounds monotonous and emotionless. For a character that's supposedly is going through some form of hell, this is not fitting.

All in all, I enjoyed playing this game and am looking forward to playing the next game from this franchise. For that reason, I want to recommand this game to anyone looking into it. Just don't expect this to be on the scariness level as games like outlast and amnesia.
