139115051.review:
|REC Review|

Bendy And the Ink Machine manages to perfectly recall the old and beloved cartoon style of the 80s/90s, through the use of vintage effects and drawn sketch graphics; supported by a refined and interesting plot.

Pros:
-Graphics, animations and voice acting are good, not perfect but still inherent to the old style
-Very simple and stripped-down gameplay, good for those who are used to simple but challenging tasks
-Interesting plot, not fully explained but understandable
-Mediocre AI, remaining in the standards of similar types. Easy to manage, given their slowness or poor deduction
-Little terror effect, lots of vintage effect and mystery

Against:
-Frequent bugs, sometimes trick lights or effects but shouldn't cause too much trouble for anyone
-Gameplay too small, few possibilities; which was fixed with the sequel "Bendy And The Dark Revival"
- Good plot, but short. Easily manageable in a few hours, frankly not totally worth the price
- Mediocre, slow and weak AI. There are almost never moments of struggle or anxiety

Conclusions:
It manages to do its job, which is to give the player an adventure in a mysterious world submerged in mysterious monsters, with a dark past and an uncertain future. It's not perfect, but acceptable

Rating: 5/10

Love the graphics and style.  It is so unique that you enjoy just walking around and checking out everything.  I am not fond of stealth games, I prefer to be given a weapon to fight the enemies.  Bendy pairs both stealth and fighting, which I appreciate, but I do really hate hiding in cabinets waiting for the ink demon to pass by, I never want to leave!!

Having said that, it is still a very cool game.  The weapons you get a cool and though the "fighting" sometimes is a little off (clicking on my controller, noticed a little lag in response) I still enjoy those scenes a lot.  Otherwise the puzzles are pretty straightforward, with many just grabbing x items and bringing them to a central location (and running, hiding from some enemy).  

It's not really scary, at all...but heart pumping nonetheless when you are running from Slender Man dripping ink all over the place (and the other lesser demons throughout).  Bendy might pop out of corners every now and then, but I found those more funny than anything else.  Come on, he is adorable!

Bought the next in the series, will be playing that too and would LOVE to see more in the future.

138936178.review:
VOICE OF CIRCUITS

"It's my second week working for Joey Drew, and I can already tell it's going to be a real piece of work. I was just minding my business, working on my animations, and suddenly, a pipe burst behind me! My pants were wet with ink all the way to my waist when I got to the Music Department. Luckily Sammy has that pump in his office. The ink flooded my office, and it took a day to drain. I'm telling you, this ink Machine causes way too many problems to just have around here. Ink flowing to every room. If this happens one more time, I quit."

138879786.review: The game is fantastic visually, but that is about as much good as I can say. The horror elements are not helped by the style of the game; excluding the unoriginal cardboard cutout jumpscares, the only real horror are the chasing scenes and they aren't really that scary. The game's story is not very moving, I never felt like I had grown attached to anyone or felt any response when they got involved in certain events, especially Henry who's comments often felt disconnected from the surprise and horror he was facing. I also never felt like there was any real conclusion, just a lot of leftover puzzle pieces that never fit together. And I know the achievements are not a mandatory part of the game, but many require access to doors and chests that cannot be interacted with until random objectives are completed which was tedious to obtain only a handful and put me off from their completion.

138413732.review:
[h1]Delve into a Dark Cartoon Nightmare in Bendy and the Ink Machine[/h1]

‏

[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Bendy and the Ink Machine is a thrilling and atmospheric horror game that takes players on a haunting journey through the twisted world of a forgotten cartoon studio. Developed by Joey Drew Studios, this unique title combines elements of classic animation with spine-chilling suspense, creating an unforgettable gaming experience. With its intriguing storyline, captivating art style, and intense gameplay, Bendy and the Ink Machine immerses players in a dark and eerie world.

‏

[h1]Graphics and Art Style: A Nostalgic Nightmare[/h1]
The graphics and art style of Bendy and the Ink Machine capture the essence of early animated cartoons while infusing them with a sinister twist. The monochromatic visuals, punctuated by splashes of vibrant ink, create a visually striking and unsettling atmosphere. The character designs are both charming and menacing, as iconic cartoon characters take on a more macabre appearance.

‏

[h1]Gameplay Mechanics: Puzzles and Tension[/h1]
Bendy and the Ink Machine excels in its gameplay mechanics, offering a seamless blend of puzzles, exploration, and tense encounters. As players progress through the episodic storyline, they'll encounter various puzzles that require critical thinking and attention to detail to solve. The challenges range from deciphering codes to manipulating machinery, keeping the gameplay fresh and engaging throughout.

‏

[h1]Storyline and Lore: Unraveling the Secrets of the Ink Machine[/h1]
One of the strongest aspects of Bendy and the Ink Machine is its captivating storyline and deep lore. The game unfolds in chapters, each revealing a piece of the intricate narrative puzzle. Players take on the role of Henry, a former animator who returns to the abandoned Joey Drew Studios, only to find a nightmarish version of his past creations.

‏

The narrative is rich with mystery, suspense, and unexpected twists, which steadily unveil the dark secrets behind the Ink Machine. The lore is carefully crafted, leaving players eager to uncover the truth behind the studio's demise and the origins of the ink-based horrors that now roam its halls. The storytelling is top-notch, immersing players in a compelling narrative that keeps them invested in the game's world until the very end.

‏

[h1]Atmosphere and Sound Design: Hauntingly Memorable[/h1]
The atmospheric qualities of Bendy and the Ink Machine are truly exceptional. The combination of the eerie art style, haunting soundtrack, and ambient sound effects effectively creates an atmosphere that envelops players in a sense of dread and wonder. The creaking floors, distant echoes, and subtle whispers contribute to the game's chilling ambiance, making each exploration a tense and unforgettable experience.

‏

The voice acting deserves special mention, with the cast delivering stellar performances that bring the characters to life. From Bendy's mischievous chuckles to Alice Angel's seductive allure, the voice work enhances the overall immersion and adds depth to the already engrossing narrative.

‏

[h1]Replay Value and Extra Content: Unlocking the Mysteries[/h1]
Bendy and the Ink Machine offers significant replay value through its hidden collectibles and multiple endings. Each chapter is filled with hidden objects and audio recordings that shed light on the game's lore, providing extra incentives for players to explore every nook and cranny of the studio.

‏

Additionally, the multiple endings give the game an extra layer of depth, encouraging players to replay the game and make different choices to witness alternative outcomes. This feature not only extends the

138350352.review:
For the people saying this game is good:
Is this good for the experience? Would blind players enjoy this?
Or is your nostalgia fueling a sort of ignorance?

For the people saying this game is bad:
Yes, I hear you. I beat it in under 4 hours with only 17 more achievements to unlock, with my only fuel to replay the game being the unofficial VR mod.

Please keep in mind; this game was birthed from the lead creator wanting to experiment with a 2D art style in a 3D world.
Not everyone can pace their stories well, especially for a chapter based game. 
Story writing takes time to get good at, Scott Cawthon (FNaF Franchise) being a prime example.

Chapter 3 can be a grueling task of:
  - Gather 3 things.
  - Bring them to Alice.
  - Don't die.
These tasks and the true reason why you are doing them doesn't become clear until the end of the next chapter, and most people don't make the connection.

With the story telling a little oddly placed, connected story elements not becoming immediately clear to the player, Bendy and the Ink Machine feels greatly inferior to its successor, Bendy and the Dark Revival.

MY VERDICT: Wait until a sale, you might get both major titles for $20 in a bundle. Bendy and the Dark Revival is a much better game.

138314346.review:
I don't often write reviews but this experience was so aggressively mediocre I feel obliged.

First off, the game is brief. Even with some confusion and wandering, I clocked in at right around four hours. First, pros: The game has a unique art style, the voice acting is decent, and it has an okay atmosphere sometimes.

Cons: this is just barely a game. The combat that exists is as bare bones as possible, puzzles are insultingly simple, and the game feels like it's mostly padding even with the short run time. The whole thing just feels extremely amateurish, and there are better options in the indie horror genre.

138311877.review:
Buggy and short.

Saving anywhere in level 2 doesn't work. When you load you're back on level 1.

Saving in the first half of level 3 will return you to the start of level 3 when you load it. Additionally, pausing in the first half of level 3 causes a pause screen glitch where the pause screen won't go away and your character can still move around but you've lost half of your controls.

After you get into the second half of level 3 the game plays smoothly.

After two complete playthroughs the game has me registered at just over 7 hours. Steam has me logged at 11.4 hours so that's over 4 hours of lost time due to faulty saves.

It's a neat game that feels like a dumbed-down ripoff of BioShock placed in an art studio. It's worth playing once but I wouldn't pay more than $5 for it.

One the titans of indie horror games, heck a titan of just the indie genre as a whole: Bendy and the Ink Machine. I really enjoyed the mystery element of it and trying to figure out what's really going on in this studio. Sure the gameplay isn't really all that functional, and I feel like they DEFINITELY could've done some stuff better (Looking at you chapter 3, nobody likes dumb, slow, boring and drawn out fetch quests.) but it's still fun. 
Truth be told, I only bought this because I was interested in the sequel but then realized that if I wanted any idea of what on earth was going on in that game, I would need to play the first installment of this 2 part series. So I did and I enjoyed it. It was an overall good experience from the beginning to the end, and I look forward to the dark revival. 7/10

Es un juego con una premisa interesante y la historia aunque nada especial tiene algo de atractivo, pero el gameplay es aburridisimo y los puzzles son mas densos que desafiantes, la mayoria (hasta donde jugue) son buscar una tuerca y tenes que recorrerte 10 pasillos con piezas hasta que la encontras, el siguiente es abrir una valvula que esta del otro lado de los pasillos y los siguientes son encontrar 2 valvulas o 2 tuercas o 5 valvulas y 5 tuercas, la verdad se hace mas tedioso, especialmente con la idea de que tiene un combate super basico donde aparecen unos enemigos que te spamean golpes y vos tenes que spamear primero para no morir ya que no hay otra mecanica que pegarles con el click, y si caminas hacia atras como intentando esquivar te pegan igual o sea que no tiene ningun sentido hacer otra cosa que solamente golpear, y bueno es basicamente eso, caminar una velocidad de un metro por día, haciendo puzzles de la tuerca o la valvula y spameando a los enemigos que spammean en tu cara o en tu espalda.
 Entiendo el atractivo del pseudo mickey mouse diabolico endemoniado en la empresa maldita de dibujos animados, por otro lado el estilo narrativo me recuerda bastante a Bioshock, y supongo que para algunos eso puede ser suficiente para pasarse el juego y disfrutarlo pero el gameplay me parece muy malo incluso para este tipo de juegos que por cierto apenas tienen gameplay, sino son de ir a punto "A" a punto "B", pero no es excusa para que sea tan engorroso, lento y malo, tampoco ayuda tener unos "puzzles" tan aburridos .
 Por el Lado grafico ni siquiera quiero opinar, tengo un 5800x3d 32gb de ram y una 6700xt y en juego en ssd y tira bajones de fps y aunque tengas 165 fps clavados a veces se siente que patea o hace stuttering. Y por último otro tema que es insoportable es que en algunos objetos o puertas (no todas) tenes una especie de "auto apuntado" que te absorve la mira hacia ellas y de pasada genera una especie de aceleracion del mouse, lo que hace que el 50% del tiempo que quieras mover la camara de repente termines apuntando a cualquier lado o tengas que corregir dos o tres veces movimientos excesivamente basicos, el desarrollador que programó eso no se como fue capaz de conseguir trabajo ya que hasta para jugar con joystick es insoportable que haga eso la cámara.
 En fin creo que esta muy sobrevalorado, tampoco es tan genial la historia como para pasar por alto que todo el resto sea impresentable, por esta razon no lo puedo recomendar.

En términos de terror, esta muy desactualizado para el día de hoy (2023), acuérdense que este juego vino por la era de Five Nights at Freddy's...

[h1]My review after play the whole game with all achievements[/h1]

[b]The good side:[/b]

1. In general terms, the game is a good proposal in horrr games, not the most scary game, but when you're into the history, you can't stop playing.

2. One of the things that I love the most is the graphics of the game, that cartoon style in the 3d format is a good point of the whole game, just beautiful.

3. When it comes to gameplay, the game doesn't feel repetitive, all the chapters are different, making the game more enjoyable. The game is not made to make you bored of it, you'll feel the need to stay playing until you finish the game.

4. The characters have a good history behind, are not boring or have common personalities.

5. For the last point, the music, the settings for all the atmosphere and all that kind of stuff makes you more into the history.

[b]The bad side:[/b]

1. The bug IS FULL OF BUGS. In my adventure for collect all the achievement, I had several headaches after two of my games were deleted for no apparent reason.

2. Not only did I encounter issues with autosave, but also with other bugs such as the infinite pause screen and the non-functional "esc" button. Specifically, in chapter five, I found myself locked in a room with no possible way to open the doors after loading the game.

3. A lot of other minor bugs, not such a terrible thing but they can be annoying.

[b]FINAL SCORE: 3.5/5 ★★★✰✰ (If we take apart the bugs, I can honestly say It's a 4.5/5)[/b]

136005706.review:
Yeah, I actually kinda loved this game! I dunno what to say so I'm just making a list of pros and cons.

First, with the Cons:
- Bugs, the game is kinda bugged, especially with save files, but nothing that bad, if it bugs or something, reinstalling the game or just restarting the game will fix the issue.
- Combat system, yeah this is kinda bullcrap, it's just hitting the enemy, wait some 0.5 seconds, hitting the enemy again, and wait, and hitting the enemy, repeated til' it is dead.
- Duration: 100% the game may take 30 hours or more, but the game itself, the 5 chapters, only will last like, 5-9 hours, so yeah, it is not very long, it is actually very short, but it is very enjoyable.
- It is not that scary.. I mean, the game is fun and everything, but at least, only the first time is kinda scary, but only the first time, and even if we count the first time we play, it is not that scary tbh.

Now the pros:
- OST: The ost its not like "I love hearing this" type of ost, but it is more like "this ost is so fitting with the ambient" type of ost, its pretty well done.
- Graphics and Art Style: The art style of this game is pretty unique, and the graphics, are well-looking, not the most beautiful game you will see, but it is far from being ugly.
- Story: The story is well-written, many people seem to hate the bendy's story, but I think it is pretty much well-written, since the game's creator had the story written, since he created the chapter 1 of the game in Feb 10 of 2017.
- Price: As I mentioned before, the game is kinda short, but the price at least on steam is pretty much fine, 20 dollars isn't as bad as you may think, and in some countrys (like mine) the game is like 10 dollars, so yeah, the price is pretty much fine.
- 100% the game: Making all the achievements of this game is pretty fun, the only achievement I hated while 100% the game, was the soup achievement of the 3rd chapter, aside that, all the achievements were fun to get!

Conclusion.
The game is pretty fun, I don't think its scary for many people, but I think it is scary enough, and that the game is pretty much enjoyable, if you like horror games but short games, then Bendy And The Ink Machine might be a game for you buddy!

135908722.review:
Bendy and the Ink Machine is like taking a trip back in time to the early days of animation - if those early cartoons were all about creepy, ink-based monsters, that is. The game is a twisted mix of whimsy and horror, with enough jump scares to make even the bravest player squeal like a cartoon mouse.

The graphics are spot-on, capturing the look and feel of vintage cartoons with a dark twist. The sound design is equally impressive, with creaking floors, screeching violins, and the constant drip-drip-drip of ink serving as the perfect backdrop to the game's spooky atmosphere.

The gameplay is a mix of puzzle-solving and stealth, with plenty of scares thrown in for good measure. You'll spend most of your time sneaking around the abandoned animation studio, trying to avoid the twisted ink creatures that lurk around every corner. And when you do get caught - well, let's just say you'll know it when you see it.

But the real star of the show here is Bendy himself. This ink-based monstrosity is equal parts adorable and terrifying, with his wide grin and soulless eyes. He's like Mickey Mouse's evil twin - if Mickey Mouse was into satanic rituals and had a taste for human flesh, that is.

All in all, if you're looking for a game that will make you jump, scream, and maybe even laugh a little, Bendy and the Ink Machine is definitely worth checking out. Just make sure you're not playing alone in the dark - unless you want to be spooked out of your mind, that is.

135761307.review:
Bendy and the Ink Machine is a 1st person puzzle game with light horror elements. This isn't a bad thing, and it excels at what it sets out to do.

The atmosphere is broody and the art design is captivating. Enemy designs aren't scary, but I still really liked them, my favourite being The Projectionist. The game has some decently intense moments with some really good sound design, but the best moments are spent listening to the audio logs, unravelling the lore and just getting lost in the massive expanse of the old studio's puzzles and secrets.

Characters in this game are surprisingly good. BATIM is well written, delivering a solid plot about the "new age" of film and how it changed the industry and affected animation studios. I can't wait to play The Dark Revival and see how it ties into this game's story.

Bendy and the Ink Machine is good. Some consider this to be "baby's first horror game" and I can see that, (imo that's Little Nightmares, but to each their own), however, I came for the stellar art direction and narrative and BATIM sure as hell delivered.

8/10

Boris deserved better and i miss him.

134966192.review:
For being one of the first games to utilize this 5-chapter release format; it's still one of the strongest entries going. Each chapter has its own unique strengths and weaknesses, which I'll go into detail in later. First off I wanna go over some of the game's universal pros and cons.
For starters; the entire game has a wonderful aesthetic, bringing one of the most unique art styles to horror gaming. The enemies walk a fine line between charming and creepy, somehow finding a great balance between the two. The worldbuilding is simply incredible as well. This game is so full of secrets that it offers a ton of replayability to find everything.
My two biggest issues with the overall gameplay were the slow movement speed and overall weak weapons.
With the overalls out of the way; now it's time to go in depth with each chapter.

Chapter 1. Despite being monotonous at times; serves as a decent introduction to the world and the stakes at hand. The main quest of this level is pretty simple, and aside from one chase sequence is completely devoid of enemies; though the chapter still manages to provide an unsettling atmosphere. More or less a prelude to the hell you've wandered into. A hell that gets expanded upon in...

Chapter 2. The stakes get higher as we venture deeper into Joey Drew Studios. This chapter definitely ups the ante with several waves of enemies that must be defeated; along with a final chase sequence akin to the first chapter. However, it does feel that Sammy Lawrence was a little underused as an antagonist. This chapter manages to balance its tense and scary moments with a few well-placed humorous ones in a way that doesn't feel like tonal whiplash. It's easy enough to figure out the chapter's various puzzles; though the first time I played, the final chase took some trial and error. All in all, a very solid chapter that builds on the first one, as well as sets up...

Chapter 3. I played the game twice before penning this review; and the biggest differences in my two playthroughs were in this chapter. I will say this is one of the more hit-or-miss chapters of the game; as the whole chapter is built around doing a series of fetch quests for Alice Angel, while attempting to evade the Butcher Gang; both of these parties making their first appearance in this chapter. Bendy himself MAY also show up. During my first playthrough I didn't encounter Bendy at all in this chapter; but during my second run he showed up a fair amount of times. It is during this chapter especially where the weak weapons really begin to pose a problem. This goes ESPECIALLY for the syringe; which is honestly one of the weakest weapons I think I've ever seen in a game. The pipe doesn't fare much better. The axe is okay; though even with that, enemies like the Projectionist and the Butcher Gang themselves are still massive damage sponges. The actual fetch quests themselves felt quite boring without Bendy's interference the first time around. When he finally did decide to show up during my second playthrough he did give me more of a challenge; forcing me to find a hiding spot since he can't be killed. This chapter also does provide some of the most striking imagery of the whole game.

Chapter 4. This chapter really ratchets up the creep factor in the early stages with some truly scary scripted events early on. The setting of an amusement park warehouse is cool; though having the carnival minigames as mandatory to progress ranged from creative to rage-inducing. Specifically; the milk toss was probably the most infuriating thing in this entire game. I really enjoyed Bertrum's boss fight; though the Projectionist didn't add anything from his first appearance. The final boss fight with Brute Boris was fairly difficult the first time around; but once you figure out what to do for each stage it's actually rather easy.

Chapter 5. The final chapter of the game has some of its best and worst segments. The spyglass was a neat touch; with its [spoiler] ability to see previously hidden messages [/spoiler] adding instant replay value since [spoiler] it can be used in all previous chapters too [/spoiler]. The boat section frankly sucks; between having to hold down the throttle and constantly destroy debris in the paddlewheel it was one of the most monotonous sections of gameplay overall. What follows it is a constant barrage of enemies; one that just keeps spawning in an endless and overwhelming slogfest until the game arbitrarily decides to cease. After it is a maze section, followed by the final confrontation with Bendy's twisted form. The final boss fight is easy enough to figure out; and once it's done you're greeted with quite a potent ending. I won't spoil it.

Tl;dr BATIM has its share of highs and lows, but overall was a very enjoyable game that I'd highly recommend.

134605005.review:
Nice visual style, interesting universe, good narration & OST. But the rest is just agressively mediocre, sometimes terribly basic. I don't think i'm asking too much to a "little" indie horror game here. Boring and insipid experience. Unlike what it seems, this is mostly Amnesia x Bioshock x early Disney gone wrong. It's more than just classic stealth+horror, and not for the better.

-Moving is painful: walk/sprint are much too slow, animations make it even worse.

-Incredibly archaic stealth and combat. You'll spent more time hitting monsters than actually running away from them. And when that happens, you just have to hide in one of the cabinets scattered around the levels. You can do it right under your foe's nose. He won't care and will leave you alone. There's no real challenge, no real threat. Definitely not scary.

-""Puzzles"" are hardly puzzles. The gameplay usually involves going into a room, picking stuff, using stuff on obvious designated machine. Everything feels artificial. Bendy failed to keep immersed, it was constantly reminding me that it's a video game and that i had to do errands for it. One protagonist even go as far as calling you [i]"little errand boy"[/i]. It's almost like they're self aware... 

I could probably recommend it solely on the basis of the artistic direction if it wasn't for a save bug i just had. I found out the game didn't properly save my progress, and that i had to go through another god awful chapter and fight some god awful boss AGAIN.  No way i'm doing this again. Other people had the same issue and i don't think the devs intend to fix it after 6 years. Never had that kind of severe problem before, even with 25yo games. Uninstalled.

3/10

its flaws are so prosaically obvious (interaction is never more then heavily railroaded Bioshock For Babies, lets player mugging, story is slathered in worthless indie horror matpat vagueness) that i feel like a hack even namechecking them. but these things dont gather big fandoms without some sort of magnetism and honestly I Get It. it rly clicked in the third chapter, which is a showcase for some of the games biggest weaknesses (not being able to interact with a thing that seems intractable until the game Says So never stops being irritating, the combat doesnt have any real Options, the repetitive fetch quest structure [tho it is at least a bit compellingly Ritualistic]) but also just goes super hard on its environment and fleeting glimpses of moderately colorful characters. its Cool To Exist In, and the procedural presence of the ink demon/showdown with the projectionist are absolutely the most compelling horror in the whole thing that shit kinda fucked me up! none of the other chapters were that vivid to exist in for me, tho each of them has at least something that captured my imagination (again usually environmental) and some clearly lovingly crafted flourishes

most of what it has to offer is inoffensive first person adventure game stuff that just happen to be the way u interact with these rickety sticky cold nighty spaces (the ink itself somehow stays vivid as an environmental touch the entire time, i was Always subconsciously avoiding the places it spills from the ceiling), but the spaces are super cool, and if thats all i ask from a walking simulator ig thats fine enough for me here. if i didnt like it more its because i find the theorybait storytelling the opposite of compelling which leaves me feeling a lil hollow on it. even then, there are some moment-to-moment narrative bits that i appreciate, like everything with good ol boris. dont take any of this as a sign that u, autistic person who knows all ab the lore, should not infodump to me about it, i would Love That please hmu

134269058.review:
I do not write reviews ever but I am so compelled by the awful latter half of this game to do so.

The beginning of this game was interesting, the concept is cool and the art direction is great. For the first 2 chapters, it at least felt like it knew what it wanted to be, and although it was clear the game wasn't high budget and wore its influences on its sleeve, it had something to offer and I was immersed. Then the next 3 chapters happen.

Through every chapter we are introduced to multiple new mechanics, that are either very poorly designed and integrated into the story, serving very little purpose, or are pretty much immediately forgotten about and underutilised. The game feels very much like the devs said "Wouldn't this be cool?" and just added it into the game with not all that much forethought. Originally, it seems to play like a survival horror game...and then it sort of turns into a boss-rush with awfully designed bosses and combat mechanics. 

The story also takes a very quick nose dive, it pulls you in pretty well in the first couple chapters but as the story unfolds it becomes incredibly apparent how shallow and underdeveloped these characters are. You learn very little about Henry the main character. You really have no reason to care about him, why he's there, or what his relationship was with Joey Drew. And as a villain, Joey Drew is incredibly underwritten and his motivations are boring. I would not be so nitpicky with the story, had the gameplay been interesting or enjoyable in any facet but I found myself often STRUGGLING to push myself through the last 2 chapters because the combat and 'stealth' were excruciating to get through. And so with the story being the only prop, its incredibly disappointing to see characters like Alice be thrown to the wayside or used as a deus ex machina.

This game is living proof that a concept or art direction do not make a good game, and its a shame that it came out the way it did considering the concept. If it had just stuck to one genre and really honed in on a FEW game mechanics rather than just throwing shit at the wall and seeing what sticks every chapter, it could've been something special. I think the stealth should've been developed further particularly. 

I hope the second game is planned out better in some capacity, and figures out what it wants to be. I think Bendy and the Ink Machine blowing up during its first one or two chapters being released was to its detriment, and I hope the devs took the time between games to fully realise their vision.

3/10

134098190.review:
This game feels like they made it up as they went along, and if they had some sort of plan, it was completely tossed out by chapter 5.

This is one those games that have characters will look great on the shelves of Hot Topic. It is a cool art style, but the janky movement and the “you can only hold one item so we can artificially inflate the game” mechanics.  

Boss fights that pretty much require you to die so you can take advantage of glitches and the way it keeps your progress after every death.  There’s no defense or any way to keep you from getting hit.  So 500 times down the ink tunnel just so you can make a little progress on unfair bosses each time until you succeed. 

Not to mention an ending that felt like someone pulled a “Hey!  I have an idea that would be cool!” right before they finished the game without any thought of the beginning of the game. In fact, this game feels like it was made up of a lot of “Wouldn’t it be cool?!” parts and they finally realized there was an audience that wouldn’t care about lore or the fact that the elevator button is still bugged. But hey!  Go down to Hot Topic and grab that Boris doll today! This game is so cool looking!!

133995987.review:
TL;DR:
Gives vibes of an underdeveloped (story wise) version of a BioShock rip off, some elements of the game are extremely unbalanced namely the boss fights, often wasn't sure what was going on but for the cheap price tag and being a game you can easily reopen at any point it's worth the few bucks. (If this was more than 20$ this review would be much different).
Overall: 3.5/5
Character Designs: 5/5
Story: 2.5/5
Mechanics: 3/5

Some spoilers ahead:
Overall pretty good game that brings a light-hearted atmosphere to a spooky story, my problem is it seems to be trying a lot to be like the BioShock series with the ink being akin to adam with a slightly different concept of how the 'lost ones' came to fruition, especially with the whole degradation of their sanity as documented through the various holo-tapes you can find. However, as a Bioshock lover, this wasn't exactly a bad thing for me, but the story itself seemed a little underdeveloped to the point where it felt like the whole BioShock aspect was all it had going for it apart from some very nice character models. I often found myself wondering what was going on, with the 'current objective' being dumbed down to the point where it also didn't help whatsoever. I did enjoy many of the game's smaller aspects such as the mini carnival in chapter 3 or 4? idk, as well as just small things like the squeaking bendy dolls and cut outs. However much larger aspects were very annoying such as the game feeling very unbalanced with the whole constantly losing your weapon, to the boris fight being harder than the final fight with bendy, somehow getting a tommy gun ? as well as the random achievement to get more kills than alice and tom in chapter 4 or 5 idk anymore, which was incredibly hard granted if you died there was no chance you'd get it so you'd have to restart, which as a achievement hunter is very annoying.

My partner bought me this game for Christmas, but I only started playing it a little under a month ago. And in case you couldn't tell by me already having aced all the achievements and put a fair few hours into the game, I LOVE it, which is actually quite rare for games these days, at least in my eyes. The gameplay might be a simplistic, and the objectives aren't very nuanced by any means (looking at you chapter 3 -_-), but the story, characters and all around atmosphere of this game is absolutely brilliant. It reminds me a lot of Bioshock and Outlast, and the art style is very fun, using cell shading to make it look cartoonish for real, just like Borderlands. I've bought myself the sequel and am currently going through it. That is the level of impressed that this first game has instilled in me. If you love horror and interesting stories, this is your game. 

8/10, only reason it's not higher is because of the simplistic gameplay, but I guess it helps you enjoy the rest of the game more thoroughly.

133394479.review: I really wanted to enjoy this game, the art style is interesting and while there are frustrations with the gameplay I still wanted to see it through. However, Chapter 3 was when my problems started: First, the game will randomly decide to stop actually saving your progress even when you manually save, meaning the only way to guarantee that a real save has triggered is to exit out of the game after saving and starting it up again at that specific save. Annoying but not unbearable, happened to me in Chapter 2 so my progress to Chapter 3 had to be redone. I get to Chapter 3 making sure my save files are working, but woops turns out if you save after taking the elevator in Chapter 3 and close the game it soft locks you so you cannot progress when you start again. OK, no big deal I'll just redo Chapter 3 and save after the required event takes place instead. So I get that done, and woops turns out if you save and close the game after the required event it soft locks you again. I cannot continue playing a game that soft locks like this and also doesn't reliably save your progress; takes the fun out of a game when you don't know when you're going to have to replay huge sections of it. This seems to be a common problem, and since it has not been fixed and the next in the series is already released and being worked on I wouldn't expect to see it resolved any time soon. If my experience has not deterred you, then take a look over at their fandom wiki bugs page.

133343129.review:
There's a lot I really like about this game.  The visuals still hold up and look amazing, the ink world is super cool and interesting, and the sound design is pretty good too.  When the game works, it can be a good experience.

That said, there's a few gameplay issues.  The combat ranges from passable to frustrating.  It can also be very easy to miss whatever you need to click on in the environment, and get stuck.  If you do play the game, don't be afraid to look up a guide.

I could forgive the game for its faults, it is an indie game after all, and I feel t he overall experience is still pretty good.  What I cannot forgive is the state of the game.  It likely wasn't like this at first, but on Windows 10 at least it's a mechanical nightmare.  I've had to reset my progress several times, and it's infuriating.  I've had to reset to checkpoints because my game broke, I've had to reset chapters entirely, and I've had to restart the entire game.  I had to restart the entire game from chapter 3 because the game either didn't save any of my progress, or deleted it.  The scariest thing about this game is worrying about if it's going to save anything or not.

133331000.review:
[h1]Gameplay: 3/10[/h1]
[h1]Graphics & Sound: 9/10[/h1]
[h1]Narration: 7/10[/h1]

✔️ Great graphics and environment design.
✔️ Cool ambience.
✔️ Nice music.

💭 The narration feels... superficial. Like, the main character's motivations don't look very deep, and the antagonists are just edgy demon cartoons. There might be something more explicited later in the game, but for what I had the patience to play it all seems very plain and basic.

❌ The gameplay is a huge drag. Most of the time you're following unclear indications that lead you to crawl through big levels again and again to find unnoticeable objects, without any indication that you're following the right lead before you find the thing you're looking for. Again and again I found myself looking for walkthroughs online to help me find the stuff I am looking for, or even make sure I understood the hints right, and honestly spending so much time on wikis is kinda ruining the ambience.
❌ It was bearable, barely, but bearable until I hit a part where you have to look for items through a sprawling level, way larger than anything I had to face until now, with a constant menace chasing me into hiding places repeatedly, to avoid which you have no other choice than to wait. That's what made me give up the game - it was annoying until then, but from that point it became simply unplayable for me.
❌ The controls cannot be changed at all. So if you have an AZERTY keyboard you have to install a new language setup to be able to play the game...

So, I do not recommend this game because of its awful level design and game design. A shame really, because the art direction is really cool.

Knowing nothing of the game but its hyped fan following I went in expected good things. Instantly you're welcomed with the aesthetically pleasing setting with an overall intriguing story and dark atmosphere. Although you quickly discover this is all the game really has to offer. When it comes to the actual game play, it leaves much to be desired.

The game heavily wants to be a bioshock clone which it somewhat succeeds at from a world perspective but in between these small glimmers of hope, you're given nothing but tedious fetch quests to fill your time. This slightly improves as the chapters progress but by that time, you've already lost interest. Combined with its somewhat questionable combat and its incredibly buggy nature, it ultimately turns out to be chore to play through. For the amount of hype this game received it feels like a wasted opportunity honestly.

132682992.review:
I want to give this game a good review. I really do. It does so much right. It's great, even. But there are some fundamental flaws that make it absolutely infuriating and I can't believe haven't been fixed since it's been released.

I write this while I wait through the chapter 5 cut scene for the 5th time. This was after playing chapter 3 5 times and chapter 4 3 times because the save system is absolutely broken. I was going for 100% achievements, yes, so I expected to play a couple chapters a few times, but the reason why I had to was not what I was expecting. The game literally bugs and doesn't save your progress a LOT. If you notice Bendy in the bottom right, you better quit the whole game and reload, otherwise if you quit and reload the game later all your progress is just gone. I lost two and a half chapters to this, and I almost gave up on the game then. I persevered and replayed since the achievements stuck and I knew exactly what to do, but the fact that a game that has been out this long still has these glitches is unforgivable. 

                     
Overall I really want to like this game, but after spending 10 hours and almost half of that was replaying parts I had already played, not because I was  100%ing it, but because the game is broken, I have a hard time recommending it. YMMV 

Addendum: Don't expect your soup pickups to persist between save and quit, because they don't. You have to replay the chapter from start to finish to get those achievements.

131356449.review:
[h1] PROS: [/h1]
[list]
    [*] Interesting dark story and mystery.
    [*] Awesome, gorgeous art style.
    [*] Good horror atmosphere and adrenaline rush.
    [*] Good music.
    [*] Top notch voice acting.
[/list]

[h1] CONS: [/h1]
[list]
    [*] The combat is terrible. You can't change your cross hair and you can easily miss.
    [*] You can't dodge/you run slow when you fight so you must cheese/sit on barrels etc.
    [*] Short game play. You can speed run through whole chapters.
    [*] TONS OF BUGS !!! Saving bug, stuck bosses, missing actions, etc.
    [*] The final boss is horrible. He's flash and you're a snail. Terrible combat.
    [*] Glitched achievements.
    [*] Glitched collectibles, you must collect them all in a single run and too many soup cans in a chapter.
[/list]

[h1] OVERALL: [/h1]
I loved the art style and story, but this game has too many bugs, and that's the reason I don't recommend this game. You can buy it on sales if you really want, but be prepared for a "long run" of frustrations.

130948994.review:
[h1]Experienced on the Meta Quest 2. VR REVIEW![/h1]

You can view my review & gameplay here: https://youtu.be/-0LOclQHGec

Yes, you can now play Bendy and the Ink Machine in full, glorious VR thanks to Team Beef. All you need to play it is download the free VR mod from the github of Team Beef, unzip the file, and run the executable. This is one of the easiest VR mods to install. Even a complete noob can do it. Just make sure you have Bendy and the Ink Machine installed (you do need to have a purchased copy) and have your VR headset ready.

Bendy and the Ink Machine VR is absolutely the best way to experience Bendy and the Ink Machine. The visuals & sounds are excellent. You are totally immersed in this ink world. The VR interactions are not the best, but considering this is a port of a non-VR game, that's to be expected. Most of the VR interactions are of the point and click variety. There are some other basic VR interactions like swinging your melee weapon or carrying your flashlight, but again, these are very basic.

Game is running on the Unity Engine. On my RTX 3080, I was getting mostly 90 fps, although I did have some frame rate drops at times (down to 45 fps). You do have full locomotion, smooth or snap turning (you can set degree or speed of turn). You can play this game comfortably seated. 

Anyways, I hope more non-VR games get VR mods. I think it is a win-win for everyone involved. A big thank you to Team Beef for their hard work in making this mod and for making it free to the PCVR community. 

[b]VR Rating 8/10.[/b]

[quote]If you enjoyed my review, please consider joining my Steam Curator Group. You can join here: https://steamcommunity.com/groups/Oculus_WMR [/quote]

130774449.review: Really enjoyed playing Bendy and the Ink Machine from start to finish. Even though it started off fairly weakly in Chapter 1, it soon picked up, and you can really see the effect that the extra funding had on the following chapters in terms of graphics and quality, story, characters and overall story development. The style itself is very unique, and the lore behind it is fascinating, very well developed and very complimentary of the scenery. However, no game is perfect, and there were a few issues that I encountered in terms of bugs and glitches. The game clearly is not finished, and the developers pretty much abandoned it after combining all the chapters into one whole game. The bugs were frustrating at times, especially when I reached Chapter 4 and the last item I collected didn't trigger a voice line, which would've allowed me to progress further into the game, so I was stuck, with no way of moving forward. The only way to solve this was to start all over again... Surprisingly, it didn't take me long to get back to where I was. Other glitches included the game save not working, therefore progress not being saved, and also when you come back after being killed, the game puts you past the part you were at when you died, which defeats the point in you actually having to fight enemies. With all this in mind, I would still recommend this game to people who have a lot of patience. It's not a bad game by any means, it is incredible, it's just a shame that the bugs will never be fixed, because it takes away from the overall enjoyment of the game. However, I'd say they were definitely worth it in the end :)

For style I would give this game a 9/10, but implementation is a 4/10 at best.

As others have noted, the game's early chapters are a glorified walking simulator whose puzzles extend to "non-interactive item you passed by and has now become interactive after a line of dialogue!"  A lot of backtracking ensues.

When loading a checkpoint in CHapter 3, the game reverted to an earlier objective-- I had to fiddle with an elevator, ride back to the floor i had just come from, and the game re-triggered dialogue and updated the objective-- then the escort NPC got trapped in the elevator, preventing the objecive door from opening until I went back and "released them".

I've also had hostile enemies get stuck running into walls, defeating a stealth/horror sequence.

The worst was completing a series of boss fights in Chapter 4, then having the game freeze in a Chapter 5 cutscene and revert my save back before the (tedious) boss fight.

At this point I'll probably just watch it on Youtube, and you'd be encouraged to the same.

130609750.review:
This is going to be a long review but the short of it is I cannot in my right mind recommend this game in it's current state purely because of the save game glitch corrupting save files, there are multiple other reasons I cannot recommend this game however and it's a long story so strap in.

 Back when this version of the game came out, or was about to come out, there were free copies given out to folks for the previous version of the game, all 5 chapters, and then that version of the game was taken off of Steam and replaced with the final Complete version of the game, but as for all those thousands of people who had gotten the game or payed for it previously, they get a broken executable or even a blank folder because that version of the game was taken down in the update and said update wasn't done properly so nobody could play the game, but it also counted it in Steam as having bought the game so you couldn't actually purchase the final version of the game to play no could you refund and remove the deprecated version of the game already in your library, now I had attempted to do a Lets Play Steam when the final version came out and boy was that an unpleasant surprise.. my hands were tied and I could do nothing, tried Steam support, they waved it off to the devs Joe Drew Studios, so I sent an email, as did everybody else.. these emails of course were ignored, possibly because of overwelming issues the Studio was going through at the time after release, either way I had decided not to attempt to purchase the game on any other platform or support any future projects from Joey Drew Studio and The Meatly for 5 years now.. then I found out how to fix things this past Winter Steam Sale, when this whole franchise was bundled and on sale, doing some reading on other people's reports of this same issue, I had Steam remove the product from my library and cleared my Steam Download Cache and ran Cleanup and rebooted my PC and had to sign into Steam again, THEN it would actually let me purchase this game officially, and when I did and started the download, sure enough, it downloaded the whole REAL executable of the game and I could finally play this game 5 years after It had originally released.. doing some more reading and playing first hand I found some more problems, things that hadn't ever been touched since the game's final release, for better or in this case, for worse.

 Indeed clipping errors, easy sequence breaking, Achievements not triggering and of course the worst of it, the infamous Saving Bug. the last one can be worked around by closing the game out as soon as it happens preventing save file corruption, the others, not so much, and strangely for such a passionate community behind this game, I too love the concept of Bendy, the asthetic and even the story, hey this is a nice looking game, just not nice playing, strangely mods or fan patches for this game, even the cheaty ones, are practically nonexistent which is strange for such a beloved game, even though it hasn't aged well with the times..

 For the completionists out there, I also cannot recommend this game, the base story is fine to play through and doable but some achievements are IMPOSSIBLE, either from the game not registering it or just the janky physics and collisions not cooperating, or in my case both when trying to get the "Call The Milkman!" achievement which I spent a literal hour on and when the tabes were clear it still didn't register.. and the Bacon Soup Can hunting collectathon is perhaps the worst collection quest I have ever attempted in a video game, bad enough with the game's asthetic everything sorta just blends together and you can't see the cans unless you hover your crosshair over them, some are in very obscure places and the Chapter 3 of spawning it and hiding it right when you can't go back for it is BULLSHIT! I now officially hate Bacon Soup!

 I also want to point out the unlockable "Black and White Filter" quest in this game is also neigh impossible without hacking the game because of all the issues I mentioned previously plus not being allowed to die since the game saves after deaths to keep track of every time you die and you have to do it in one go on one save file without reloading the game.. it's just so cruel and ultimately not worth it, better off switching your PC to black and white mode for that filter instead..

 This game is such a love hate relationship, it's a literal cartoon purgatory, a hellscape, not just intentionally but also to try and play through! I cannot recommend this game to anyone, even when it's on sale.. hoping it's official sequel Dark Revival is more playable at least as I do love this franchise and the new game almost didn't come out at all, glad the company is still around but hope that they've learned from their mistakes on their future projects, this game has been abandoned and the studio behind it almost went away for good..

130604994.review:
Having seen the iconic Bendy face multiple times and also getting a couple of recommendations about BATIM I decided to finally bite the bullet and give it a try to see what I've been missing.

I honestly wanted to like this game. And there is a lot to like, however there are some game breaking bugs that just colossally ruined the experience for me.

The good:
* The story: interesting and arguably quite different. It will grip a lot of people wanting to find out what is happening at the animation studio and with plenty Bends and turns this game will keep you in it for its run time (which arguably is not that long but we will get to that).
* The graphics: whilst not astounding by any means in terms of realism, the graphics fit the game so perfectly and is a large part of the world building.
* Replayability: Whilst this game seems like something you realistically wouldnt want to replay, there is a very interesting twist at one point of the game, that may make you interested in replaying it. I see this as a great thing especially when this is quite uncharacteristic for a horror game.

The meh/ok:
*The atmosphere: This game had so much potential! The 1st chapter of the game did so well in terms of atmosphere. Shortly, the first chapter was something along the lines of if bioshock and amnesia the dark descent had a baby, but it was in black and white. You are left eerily uneasy as you traverse the level. The subtle jumpscares so tastefully placed in key locations... It was all so great. Why did I include it in the meh/ok section? Well... after the 1st half of the 2nd chapter all of that mystery and atmosphere starts fading away... and just keeps fading away to the point where the game becomes not scary at all. It feels like this game could have been so much better if the approach to the 1st chapter was carried over. Sadly that is not the case.
*The gameplay: Whilst the gameplay is not inherently bad, it does leave much to be desired. It follows some similar approaches to other puzzle games, but it doesn't really innovate on them. Whether its a fetch quest, sneaking around hostile (and this point completely not scary) monsters or just looking for things around the map. This gets old quite quickly and borders on becoming boring. The only thing saving this point from landing in the "bad" section is the fact that the game is not that long thus it doesn't really have enough time to get too tedious. Regardless though, the gameplay apart from a few key locations is (which were quite interesting) meh at best.
*Game length: This game is probably no more than a 4 hour game. I've said this on my other reviews but Ill say it again - I prefer shorter but more "concentrated" games rather than a diluted mess. However, I know there are plenty of people that disagree with me on this and this game is really short. The game doesn't cost £60, however at £15 you may want to consider whether or not you can spend your money better if you want a longer game.

The bad:
* Realistically, BATIM wouldn't really have any points that would make it into this section if not for.... the bugs.
I wouldn't even normally penalise a game this much for having a bug here or there, but it really heavilly relies on the severity of the bugs and sadly, BATIM gets a fat F in this department.
The short of it is - I lost my save file twice between game sessions and I also got softlocked in areas twice (thus forcing me to replay the whole chapter). This is absolutely unacceptable for a game thats being sold as a finished product.

I really wanted to like this game. And I mostly did. Whilst I wouldnt place it as high as some of the content creators I watched did, it was enjoyable. But having completely game breaking bugs like this killed the game for me and along with it this review.
I refuse to mark this game positive until these bugs are fixed (and knowing that this is a 6 year old game at this point I doubt it will happen).

TLDR:
Interesting story, great visuals, amazing atmosphere (at least initially) but with the risk of encountering the above game breaking bugs that may force you to replay a significant portion of the game...
I cannot in good conscience recommend this game, but if you're willing to risk losing your save file then give it a try.
Beware the blinking save icon.

This is one of those cases where I wish Steam had a third option, so take this as a "loosely recommend". First of all, I beat this game in under four hours, and that was taking my time and exploring, so definitely wait for a sale if you want to pick this up; I can't recommend this game at full price.

Fundamentally, I feel the game really sets up an oppressive atmosphere in chapter 1 with some great attention to atmosphere and to its art style, but this horror element never goes anywhere. You gain weapons to fight back, and this kills any suspense. There are moments where you need to sneak around, but the AI is so predictable and not-scary that it's really just a waiting game.

That's not to say I hate the game, I feel there's a lot of potential with this aesthetic and with the game's lore. Everything's fully voice acted, and the game's cartoony aesthetic remains very consistent throughout the five chapters, which is excellent. The lore isn't anything to write home about, but it's there.

TL;DR Buy this on a discount knowing you'll get five hours max out of this. If the screenshots look appealing, go for it.

130395612.review:
After revisiting the game and completing in 2022, I can definitively say this is a decent game.

CHAPTERS
-------------------------------------
Chapter 1: 10/10, A good start to the story and very simple.

Chapter 2: 8/10,  Solid chapter,  Sammy def carried it. Combat in this one is fairly easy but can get annoying at some points, Puzzles are also pretty easy

Chapter 3: 4/10, Didn't like it as much, First half started out ok, then delved into annoying and tedious fetch quests. Projectionist areas were kinda fun, Except for when you were looking for that one missing thing you can't find and you hear screaming & music coming from the other hall

Chapter 4: 5/10, Slightly better then Chapter 3, but painfully short. The ink things that create Items are a cool mechanic, especially when you have to use them for the final boss... Speaking of boss fights in this chapter.. The first one (Bertrum) is slightly a thorn to the side... Can be annoying until you beat him

Chapter 5: 6/10, It is a improvement from both Chapter 3 and 4, but it is not as good as Chapters 1 and 2. The NPC mechanic with Tom and Allison feels very poorly used, and seemingly only serves to aid you for the Lost Ones boss fight during the beginning of the chapter. The butcher gang segment down in the department area is extremely infuriating, because if you die.. You're forced to restart all over again (unless you already made a pipe already) to go all the way to that one hall, Get the ink blob, and somehow avoid them while worrying about how they could screw you over in the blink of an eye.. Onto the ending. It left me rather dissapointed then satisfied (Yes.. I know it was setting up Bendy and the Dark Revival.. But the ending felt off and last minute for some reason.) Overall, decent chapter. Lackluster ending.

VISUALS 'N STUFF
--------------------------------------------------------
Visuals: 8/10, It is rather pretty being for a stylized indie game.. so pretty infact it might set your computer on fire

Music: 7/10, Decent. some are pretty good. (Like Drawn to Darkness and Reel Fear)

Gameplay: 5/10, Not really much to do then to wield weapons, pick up items.. Pull levers.. You get the idea.

Story: 5/10, I really wanted to like the story, but quite frankly I'm divided on it. Chapters 1-2 had a intresting direction for the story to go to, Only for Chapter 5's ending to blow it last minute and offer a last minute rewrite that felt rather rushed and unnesserary.

Voice Acting: 7/10, Henry's voice for some reason makes me wanna fall asleep

And that's about it. 6/10 game. Recomend to anybody who likes the visual style of the old 1930's cartoons back in the day

130376560.review:
Cons:

* Poor / clunky controls - unable to re-bind keys
* Poor save features 
* When Bendy or monsters show up to chase you, a lot of times the game gives you absolutely no indication of where to go, so you'll usually have to 'die' and then re-try again which isn't particularly enjoyable. 
* No maps of anything so you basically just end up wandering around lost quite a bit which contributes to the aforementioned issue of not knowing where to go if a monster shows up as part of the story. 
* Boss battles - As mentioned earlier, there's very little indication of what you're supposed to do which generally results in the player having to die in order to figure it out, which is immersion breaking. 

Pros:

* Decent graphics
* They did a good job with the creepy environment

Game Length: There are 5 chapters - it took me around 4 hours to get to the end of Chapter 4 and I am stopping at this point.

Final Rating: 2 / 10 - I found very little enjoyment in this game. I had seen it was highly rated so I just wanted to try something outside of my comfort zone and I toughed it out for about 4 hours, getting to the end of Chapter 4 at the boss battle - this boss battle was poorly designed, but I still got a good chunk through it but kept dying at certain parts as a result of the absolutely abysmal control system and couldn't dodge some of the boss's attacks and finally just said eff it. Time to uninstall. Hopefully this will be more enjoyable for some other folks, it's just not my cup of tea. I generally just need a good story, good controls / interface, and some decent graphics and I'm a happy camper, but this game just didn't provide much in what I was looking for. I did like the creepy environment though, that's what made me want to try it.

I thumbed this down at first due to the chapter 3 save bug that nearly drove me to actual insanity. Uninstalled and redownloaded the game and the bug disappeared, so I'm now able to form a full opinion after completing the game. 

As well, I played Poppy Playtime before Bendy, and I think that left me slightly disappointed here- In all fairness, Poppy Playtime probably pulled a lot of inspiration from this game since this came out first, but the similarities were too familiar for them to fully excite me. Moving along-

The story line is incredibly interesting. The jump scares are well-timed, the characters are made to look genuinely unnerving, the suspense is layered on incredibly thick, and the puzzles/bosses are a nice mixture of extremely frustrating/challenging and doable. It's immersive, keeps you suspended in disbelief, and leaves you wanting more. Already downloaded Bendy and the Dark Revival (: However, I almost feel like I can't remember it very well because of how fast paced and complex it is- which could be seen as positive or negative.

Due to bug issues being entirely random (as I've heard/read), I would suggest buying this on sale. At the time I thought I was doomed to never progress in the game due to the bug, I was comforted knowing I only paid about five dollars for it. The bug doesn't effect everyone, but everyone who does get it experiences it on chapter 3, which is probably too far in the game for Steam to accept a refund. Just keep that in mind.

Overall a bad experience, no fucking clue why this game is so praised. Probably Matpat hype.

Loved every minute of this so far. The art direction, level design and audio design are bang on.

Being a horror game it can be a little scary at times. There are some carefully placed jump scares, and the game really does an exceptional job of building the atmosphere. Whilst this game does revolve quite a lot around puzzles, it doesn't take it too far and every puzzle can be solved within a few minutes so you're always having fun instead of angrily searching for the walkthrough. 

The only issues with this game are the occasional scripting problem, and the save system. Every now and then you'll encounter a script problem when the game hasn't triggered the next event, but since the game is 5 years old at this point if you search you'll find the solution.  The save system is also a bit flaky, as in sometimes it just doesn't save and the Bendy icon gets stuck in the corner. 

Overall, very excited to get the 100% in this and pick up the sequel. Strongly recommended. 

[i] Also, fucking bacon soup achievements. Why am I searching for soup [/i]

129573414.review:
Bendy and the Ink Machine (BATIM) is a fantastic game. My family has owned it on the Xbox for many years and I never get bored with it. It has only one ending that I am aware of, but this does not disuade my urge to play the game over and over.

It has excellent graphics (this may hinder laptop gaming, as I discovered, but oftentimes altering the resolution and quality will solve this issue) and a fascinating story. The thoughtful character designs and intricate scenery add to its spooky mystique. I also adore the soundtrack. There are lots of puzzles; they are not too difficult so I recommend playing without a guide unless you wish to attain the Tommy gun.

The game’s jumpscares still startle me when I play it, but some elements are silly. How close you have to get to the Bendy cutout in the first chapter (to hear the “Who put this here?” dialogue) is always funny, as are Sammy’s monologues. Despite its fantastic quality, it’s rather short and has only one ending (I believe it would work well with at least two; such as the Angel and Demon ending). I believe BATIM is worth a little less than it has been recorded as, so I bought it when it was on sale.

129522537.review:
Bendy and the Ink Machine is an episodic first-person horror survival game with Bioshock undertones. The vintage aesthetic really stands out and lends itself surprisingly well to the horror genre, and it helps make this game visually unique and interesting.

The game is mostly fetch quests and the combat isn’t very good either, unfortunately. But if you’re looking for some creepy encounters, I recommend picking this up when it’s on sale. This game was very much developed for fun, which there’s nothing wrong with, but keep that in mind while you’re playing if you run into bugs or clunky/repetitive combat. For what it is, I think it’s definitely worth playing and I’m certain that the new release of Bendy and the Dark Revival will be better. Having said that, this game did win Best Horror Game from IGN in 2017, so even with its issues, it’s still very much worth playing. (Still probably shouldn’t have won, and RE7 should have, but hey, more than a few people in the room voted for Bendy). Definitely pick it up on sale :)

129344552.review:
I wanted to like this game, and from the start it had promise!  The visual style is really cool and I loved that.

I was on Chapter 2 though and it got tedious.  What I could tell were supposed to be jump scares really were not scary and did not make me jump.  I was kind of getting bored.  I like the idea of this ink machine and what not, but I just wasn't creep'd out by the story or visuals.

You move slow, like in most games like this.  And that would be OK.  The environments are small enough where its not too tedious to go back and forth BUT then you have the "combat".  I hate when a good game (in my opinion of course) has to cram in some kind of "survival horror" aspect thinking it is scary.  The Ax you get for a weapon is slow, clunky and I swear has a negative range.  The Ink Monsters had to be on top of me for me to hit them.  for me personally I get more annoyed at this kind of mechanic, it breaks my immersion and makes me focus on a clunky combat system.  Its not scary, its frustrating I am not given the means to take care of these ink creatures (which to me aren't that scary either).  I get that to some people, that is how they enjoy games, struggling at every encounter.  But I wanted to immerse myself in the world and hear its story, not struggle to ax a few monsters.

I gave up when I was on a certain "puzzle" where I had to get an ink monster to stand somewhere.  I kept trying, even reading guides.  Most people had no problem, three times they said and the monster stood where it needed to.  It never did, it switched between four spots in the room and that was it.  I was at it for probably 20 minutes or so.  I tried to reload the game and it never stood where it needed to.  One of the spots it stood was close but the trap didn't work.  So I am only left to assume its glitched and the one spot near the trap is supposed to be under the trap.

I returned it, I feared it would try to shoe horn the "survival" element in instead of being atmospheric.  I personally just don't like that element in horror games, I don't find it scary myself, I find it annoying.  And left to assume I cant advance due to a glitch (no solutions online, none in game either) I just could not play it anymore.

129292573.review:
Fun game. It's got a real cool and creepy atmosphere and interesting lore, but the game never really hits great high notes of horror. It's got a handful of jump scares, and a few places you've got to sneak around, but it's never that hard, there's only a few enemy types, and by half-way through, I wasn't really ever scared anymore knowing what could happen and how easy it was to avoid the danger. Good to play if you're only slightly into the horror genre, but not great if you're looking for something that's absolutely dripping with horror and creepiness.

As other reviewers have noted, there's weird bugs with the save system, where if you see the bendy icon in the bottom right corner, it means the save wasn't complete, and you'll need to back out of the entire game to fix things. Usually, after getting to the end of the chapter and quitting out, I didn't lose progress, but ymmv. Also, very annoying that quitting out mid-chapter will reset the bacon cans collectibles for that chapter. However, the game is short enough that it's also not hard to get through it in an afternoon and not even worry about the save glitch.

The game has an interesting visual style and good atmosphere, but the latter half is virtually unplayable on controller. I picked the series up to play on my steam deck and there last two chapters are just incredibly un-fun and made me want a refund. 

The controls are loose and hit boxes are only a rough approximation, which is fine, unless your in a boss fight and have to keep repeating it over and over. The tipping point for me was the barge level where you have to hold down the X key to keep the boat moving, then turn around and dislodge three inks, then turn back and continue holding the X key to move forward or else you get insta-killed. If you die, you have to start over and go through the whole process again from the beginning. It took the pace of the game to a screeching halt and made me want to stop playing and refund the game.

Also, it doesn't have cloud saves so I couldn't go from my steam deck to my PC in order to use a mouse and keyboard.

129209522.review:
I have to admit, I never anticipated despising a game more than I did the emoji movie, but this game proved me wrong. From the very beginning, it becomes evident that the game fails to deliver on its promise of delivering scares. While there are a few jump scares sprinkled throughout, they lack impact and quickly fade into oblivion. Moreover, the story itself is devoid of purpose and lacks a satisfying conclusion. No matter how many theories you entertain, they cannot salvage the haphazard narrative structure that leaves players seeking closure.

Regrettably, this game falls into the realm of sheer absurdity. It had the potential to be something extraordinary, but it falters on multiple fronts. Bendy, the proclaimed threat, is frequently neglected for extended periods, as the game's focus shifts to the unimpressive Evil Alice. Her chapter is marred by tedious fetch quests that could have been reimagined to highlight Bendy's presence and feature the Projectionist as the sole character to elicit fear. The inclusion of Good Alice and Boris feels forced and inconsequential. They briefly aid the player in an unfairly challenging battle, only to vanish and reappear for the sake of comedic relief. Ultimately, their presence adds little value to the overall experience.

The final battle serves no purpose and diminishes the sole redeeming factor of the game—the unique design of Bendy. Disappointingly, this design is discarded in favor of a more brutish form, leaving players to suspect that it was abandoned for a superior iteration in the sequel.

The game is riddled with numerous glitches that severely hinder the enjoyment. Personally, I encountered difficulties accessing the archives and had to resort to manipulating files to unlock them and obtain an achievement. Chapter 5 presented an insurmountable obstacle as I found myself trapped between two unyielding doors, rendering progress impossible. Despite the game saving my location, it failed to register my actions, leaving me in an inescapable predicament.

Regarding the story, it is an incomprehensible mess. While it hints at a purgatorial setting, there is no coherent connection established between the player character and Bendy, apart from vague allusions to the player being Bendy's creator. The motivations driving Bendy's desire to kill the player character remain shrouded in ambiguity. The game attempts to delve into Evil Alice's backstory, but it is overshadowed by her theft of Boris, undermining any potential for depth. Intriguing concepts are merely brushed upon and left unexplored. The game relies excessively on audio tapes to convey emotions, neglecting the need for substantial storytelling. Surprisingly, the most development is dedicated to Joey Drew, an unremarkable character whose façade is revealed through a single tape. Boris, on the other hand, is a forgettable presence who merely serves to rescue the player. One of the incarnations of Boris unexplainably harbors animosity towards the player character. Sammy, a character who seemingly perished in Chapter 2, inexplicably resurfaces in later chapters. The lack of compelling character development and narrative depth leaves players bewildered as they traverse the studio, questioning the game's direction.

In terms of gameplay, there are brief sections of sneaking that are best hurried through rather than meticulously navigated. The absence of consequences for failure indicates that the developers themselves recognized the flaws in these sections but opted to include them regardless. Bendy and the other enemies prove to be feeble adversaries, as you can repeatedly hide in the same locker even if they spot you—despite acknowledging this issue in Chapter 4, no attempt is made to rectify it. The combat mechanics are lackluster, devoid of any blocking or dodging capabilities. Players are left with no viable strategy but to hope for a glitch or inaccessible spot where enemies cannot reach them, resulting in a dreary exchange of blows.

In conclusion, I wholeheartedly discourage playing this game and suggest instead immersing yourself in the new installment, which I have heard surpasses its predecessor in both gameplay and storytelling aspects.

128867076.review:
Bendy and the Ink Machine is basically a really dumbed down Bioshock. The game is buggy with some people (not me) experiencing one where the game won't save properly after chapter 3. The combat and puzzles are extremely barebones. The combat basically breaks down to, hit this thing 2-4 times with your melee weapon and it's dead or unkillable monstrosity that you must stealth by/run from. Puzzles are all pretty much, hit this switch or get this item and place it here. Chapter 3 is an hour to an hour and a half long series of fetch quests.

The game has a cool aesthetic (though the constant orangish/goldish tint gets old) and some decent character designs, but there's not much else here. There's almost no reason to play through this unless you're really interested in the aesthetic, you're really bad at games, or you've never played Bioshock and would like to play a far lesser game before playing a far better one.

128602494.review:
As someone who has known/played bendy for a few years I can give a solid opinion on this game

| Chapter 1 |

Chapter 1 has you play as the protagonist Henry Stein whose old work partner, Joey Drew wants to show him something in the old workshop, Joey Drew Studios, and so we enter the studio and begin our search to find what Joey wants to show you. So you stumble upon the Ink Machine, this giant machine intended in bringing cartoon characters to life. So you find the main power switch and you find out you need to put items on the pedestals to "appease the gods" as Joey says according to Wally Franks, but once all are collected you place them on the pedestals and you need to find a valve to restore the ink pressure, once this is done you head back and flip the switch and on turns the machine, you head over to the ink machine and find the room is boarded up. In curiosity you walk up to it to see what's inside and you get a jump-scare from the Ink Demon himself and so he chases you and you dash for the exit but before you can get to it, the wooden boards beneath you arent steady enough so you fall through them into this pool of ink of which you have to drain using the valves found around the area, once this is all done you find a workstation with an axe. You take it then start chopping down some boards and find yourself in this room with a big sacrificial pentagram. Upon stepping onto it you start having these flashbacks showing things like a wheelchair, the Ink Demon, the Ink Machine and others.

| Conclusion to chapter 1 |

In conclusion chapter 1 is a very well done way to start an amazing horror game and story, would recommend getting the demo before paying for the full game because you still get the same experience no matter if you get chapter 1 for free or you get it with the full game, that is if it costs money at all for the first chapter.

( I'll maybe do the other chapters soon )
